TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 October 1996, Senator O'Chee reported to the Senate on the committee's concerns with this instrument, which related to delay and possible prejudicial retrospectivity. The minister has provided the committee with information which meets our concern about retrospectivity and we will withdraw the notice. BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—
13 August 1996,
The Hon Alexander Downer MP
Minister for Foreign Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the South Pacific Regional Environment Programme (Privileges and Immunities) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No. 144.

The Regulations commence generally with retrospectivity of more than 10 months from gazettal. The Committee would be grateful for your advice on the apparent delay in making the Regulations, which, the Explanatory Statement advises, provide for obligations under an agreement signed on 21 September 1993 and which entered into force on 31 August 1995.

The Regulations properly provide that any immunity from suit conferred by the Regulations commences on gazettal. However, r. 5 provides for retrospective rights which apparently include the right to sue. This retrospectivity would benefit the SPREP but would appear to prejudice anyone being sued. The Committee would appreciate your comments on the validity of this provision and, if valid, whether it is appropriate to prejudice people in this way.
The Regulations provide for other retrospective privileges and immunities. The Committee would appreciate your advice on whether any person could have been prejudiced by this retrospectivity.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Chairman
14 October 1996
Senator B. O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

I refer to your letter of 13 August 1996 regarding questions of retrospectivity of the South Pacific Regional Environment Programme (Privileges and Immunities) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No. 144 ("the Regulations").

The purpose of the Regulations was to do no more than restore the status quo ante to SPREP, and my Department's drafting instructions to the Attorney-General's Department were explicit in this regard. SPREP was a program of the South Pacific Commission (SPC) and until 31 August 1995, on which date SPREP became an autonomous organisation when the requisite tenth ratification of the Agreement Establishing SPREP was lodged, it enjoyed the privileges and immunities enjoyed by the SPC. Technically, when SPREP achieved autonomy it lost those privileges and immunities, hence the need for their restoration. With specific reference to the question of retrospectivity, the Attorney-General's Department confirmed the acceptability of such a provision in all respects other than immunity from suit, on the basis that only the Commonwealth itself (in respect of tax) should in practice be prejudiced by the retrospectivity.
In this regard, I note that:
a. there was no activity in Australia by SPREP or its staff between 31 August 1995 and gazettal of the Regulations, hence there is no possibility of prejudice to third persons; and

b. a "retrospective right to sue" is meaningless in practice as SPREP could not have sued anyone before gazettal of the Regulations; while it is true that SPREP could now sue on a cause of action that accrued between 31 August 1995 and gazettal, it is difficult to see how there could be any prejudice in this.

By way of expansion of this last point, I might add that if SPREP were not able to sue on a cause of action that accrued in that time (between 31 August 1995 and gazettal), this would in effect confer an immunity on any person who had done SPREP a civil wrong. It would not be desirable for any person to escape liability for such a wrong merely because SPREP was not a legal entity at the time. In any event, while ever SPREP was not a legal entity, the wrong would have been suffered instead by some natural person who could have sued in his/her own name even before gazettal of the Regulations.
Yours sincerely
Alexander Downer

Commissioners' Rules No. 22 made under s.252 of the Life Insurance Act 1995

1. A note in the instrument advised that the Rules would commence on making, while the Explanatory Statement advised that they commenced on gazettal, which was a different date.

Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips)(1996) Regulations Statutory Rules 1996 No. 206
The Regulations provide for the control of the export of hardwood wood chips.

Regulations 32 and 34 do not require the Minister to give a statement of reasons for a decision to suspend or refuse an assignment of a licence.

Although regulation 36 provides that the Minister must reconsider a relevant decision within a specified time, there are no time constraints placed on the making of the original decisions which are subject to the reconsideration process.
Regulation 40 provides that the Minister may delegate powers to any officer of the Department, no matter how junior.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the joint resolution of the Parliament of 30 October 1996 which states, in part, that the Parliament `reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage';

(b) calls on the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to restore funding for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation so that the rhetoric is matched by some meaningful action; and
(c) deplores the comments of the Member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) accusing Aborigines affected by alcohol of attacking Asian troops.

In my remarks, I will attempt to answer Senator Harradine's concerns. This is not an attempt to have a long debate on this particular motion. But, Senator Harradine, because so many things in the reconciliation debate happen in the other place, we do not have a contemporary opportunity very often to address it. I am seeking only five minutes now to answer the continuing, festering racist comments that I think we see all around us on a daily basis. That is all I am seeking to do.

BREAK.PARA: Since we passed our so‐called bipartisan joint house motion last week, you can see the continuation of comments and the continuation of incidents which need to be commented on. They need to be remarked upon. It is not enough for members of parliament, in good faith, to pass a resolution which is full of rhetoric and pretty empty on action. Since that resolution was passed last week, we have seen the incident in Townsville. We have seen the distortion in the reporting of the incident in Townsville by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I believe this chamber has just as much right to comment on that matter as does the other place.

We have also heard this morning and seen in today's Daily Telegraph comments about the Chair of ATSIC, Ms Lois O'Donoghue, and inferences that there is something wrong with her earning a salary level equal to a departmental head. The simple point I want to repeat is that we passed a bipartisan motion. That motion says, in part, that we reaffirm our commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage.

We might think that is the end of it because we said we reaffirm our commitment. These were the fine words at a luncheon in May this year and in a bipartisan joint house resolution last week. But what is going on out there in the community in terms of racist comments, community division and alienation are things that are continuing. That is why I wanted the Senate to have a few minutes today not to let it pass without comment.

I take huge exception to somebody like Alan Jones editorialising on Lois O'Donoghue's right to earn a salary that is equal to that of a departmental head. The clear inference was: she is an Aboriginal woman; how could she possibly be worthy of this level of salary? We politicians have to speak up. I am taking that opportunity to speak up and to tell Alan Jones, and all the rest of those who are ill informed, who might be listening and who have no access to the information, that that salary is set by the Remuneration Tribunal—as are our salaries.

Lois O'Donoghue does not have a right to representation in terms of going in there and saying, `My salary is not enough.' This is a departmental head equivalent. I think it is objectionable that we have made this commitment to reconciliation and we allow comments like this to go unremarked upon.

I want to make two other points. You cannot make a commitment to the process of reconciliation and you cannot talk about redressing profound social and economic disadvantage when, at the same time, you reduce the budget of the Council for Reconciliation, whose job it is to bring together indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians. It is a huge task—just leading to a greater understanding about the true history of this country, about the significance of land and sea to indigenous Australians. You cannot have this commitment and, at the same time, reduce the running costs of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation by 30 per cent and take $400 million out of the budget of ATSIC.

Those are the points I want to make. We have passed a resolution; it is not enough. We might have felt good about it on the day; it is not enough. We, as politicians, have to stand up every time somebody out there continues this ill‐informed, bigoted campaign aided and abetted by the member for Oxley.

I think the Senate has a small role to play in this debate as well. That is all I wanted to say, Senator Harradine. Because of the uncertainty of what is going to happen on Thursday, I cannot accept that we should have postponed this matter to Thursday. I do not seek to delay the Senate unduly, but I do seek to make those points. Let us not sit here and be complacent about the fact that we have passed a resolution on this. Let us try to match the rhetoric with a bit of action. At the individual level, that action includes speaking up and speaking up every time the misinformation and the bigotry continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be opposing this motion. I believe the term `reconciliation' is problematic for a number of people. A number of Aboriginal representatives and groups have indicated that it assumes that we have had conciliation and that all we need is reconciliation. SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I will not be opposing the motion, I wanted to indicate that reconciliation is problematic. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I will present the government's point of view on this notice of motion. The fact is that it is time that the non-government parties started dealing in facts not fiction. It is time that Senator Kernot stopped playing politics in this important area, opened her eyes and considered the facts. The fact is that this government is committed to increasing spending on indigenous affairs and it is time that Senator Kernot realised and acknowledged that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal with the substance of her motion. She calls for a restoration of funding to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. The council had a reduction in its forward program estimates from $4.66 million to $3.5 million for 1996-97. The council has also been allowed to roll over $711,000 from 1995-96 to 1996-97, primarily to meet costs associated with the council's Australian reconciliation convention to be held in May next year and coinciding with the 30th anniversary of the 1967 referendum. This means that actual expenditure this year will be $4.195 million higher than the actual expenditure last year of $3.806 million.

That is right Senator Kernot, more will be spent on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation this year than last year. As for overall Commonwealth spending on indigenous specific programs, I point out that we will be spending more—$429 million more—over the next four years than was spent during the last four years.

The non‐government parties fail to comprehend that there is a new government in office. They fail to comprehend that the policies of the last 13 years have proven to be an unqualified failure. They fail to comprehend that this government will not play the politically correct game if it means that Aboriginal people on the ground in remote communities continue to miss out. They fail to comprehend that this government is about achieving real outcomes for indigenous Australians.

There are 300,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia, and less than 100,000 of those are adults. In the past 12 years, over $12 billion has been spent on indigenous specific programs. Despite that, indigenous Australians still have an infant moratality rate two to three times that of non‐indigenous Australians, a life expectancy rate up to 18 years less than for non‐indigenous Australians, an adult diabetes rate that runs at four times the rate for non‐indigenous Australians and falling education standards.

Those opposite would have us continue the same failed policies. Instead, we have embarked on policies that will deliver real outcomes. Despite the savings that we have made within the ATSIC budget, during the next four years the Commonwealth will spend in today's dollar terms $429 million more on indigenous specific programs than during the last four years. During the next four years we will spend an additional $97 million on indigenous health, an additional $26 million on the community housing and infrastructure program, an additional $337 million on the community development employment program and an additional $147 million on Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs run indigenous education and training programs. For all these reasons we oppose Senator Kernot's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very concerned to hear about a number of the matters raised by Senator Kernot, in particular a repeat of some of the statements being made by television and radio talkback commentator Alan Jones. There are racial overtones in quite a number of Alan Jones's comments. This is not the first time that this has occurred. It is a disgrace. I think that the radio station has some responsibility in this matter, as has Channel Nine.

SPEECH.PARA: On another occasion, on 13 September this year, on the Today show Mr Alan Jones took a sideswipe at three Chinese women who were seeking asylum and refugee status. His slur was against three Chinese women who were seeking refugee status due to their well-founded fear of persecution if forcibly returned to the PRC. Mr Jones claimed that the basis of their application was that these women wanted to have more than one child. He painted a picture of millions of people coming down from China to flood this country if their application was agreed to. Bear in mind what he said—that these women want to have more than one child. If Mr Jones had done even a tiny amount of research he would have learnt that having more children is impossible for these women, all of whom were sterilised by the PRC and one of whom had her baby forcibly taken out of her womb at 7½ months.

How do you think those people feel? How do you think the people who represent them feel? How do you think they feel in the detention centres? Alan Jones, how do you think they feel? How do you think Lois O'Donohue feels? How do you think the Aboriginals, whom she represents and serves extremely well, feel? It is time that the television stations like Channel Nine acted responsibility in this so-called racism debate.

I do not think there is a racism debate going on. There are certain allegations by xenophobic twits, but there is very little serious discussions about these matters. The joint resolution of 30 October that is before us states in part:
Parliament reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage.

It then goes on to call on the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to restore funding for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation `so that the rhetoric is matched by some meaningful action'.

I say through you, Madam President, to Senator Kernot, that I wanted a bit of time to get across paragraph (b). Hopefully, we can adjourn this matter. I know that I should have got across it but I did not think it would come in so soon, though your office did contact me by fax. It was one of the thousands of pieces of paper that come into my office. I apologise to you.

As to `deploring the comments of the member for Oxley, Ms Hanson, accusing Aborigines affected by alcohol of attacking Asian troops', I have said what I have said about the so-called racism debate. When you have a specific statement like that I believe that is something the parliament should deplore. But I wonder whether it is possible to defer this debate so that people can get across paragraph (b). I hear what Senator Troeth has said about the reconciliation issue. I know that there are areas of concern to a number of people about the way certain moneys are spent but I personally am not in a position at present—and I apologise to you, Madam President for this—to vote one way or the other on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly on this because, as a former member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, I totally support the motion that has been moved by Senator Kernot. I think that in this place we cannot underestimate the importance of our leadership on this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: There are people in this place and the other place who say, `Look, if we don't talk about it, this so‐called race debate will go away. Let's just push it to one side. If we take no notice of it, it will go away.' It will not go away. It is one of the most crucial issues on which this parliament must show leadership.

We have heard from Senator Troeth. I accept her defence of the government, but the reality is, Senator Troeth, that the government has downgraded the position of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. It has done this in financial terms. It has justified it on the basis of treating everybody equally and that, if there have to be cuts in other areas of government expenditure, then why not for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation? But we do not treat everybody equally. There were no cuts to the defence budget; there were no cuts to a number of other areas of the budget.Why single out an area of significant importance to this nation: the question of reconciliation with indigenous people?

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to comment on Senator Dee Margetts's contribution and acknowledge that there are indigenous peoples who do not accept reconciliation, partly because the focus has been on Aboriginal reconciliation. Senator Kernot and a number of other senators and I know that it is not a question so much of Aboriginal reconciliation. It is a question of non‐indigenous Australians recognising indigenous people, recognising their culture and history and coming to terms to with our past.

Of course, there are high profile people—leaders even—who say, `Let's forget the past. What does it matter?' You cannot deal with the present unless you learn the lessons of the past. So I would commend Senator Kernot's motion. I would say to government members: do not underestimate the significance of this debate; do not interpret it in crude numbers of voters who may or may not support you.
This goes to the heart of what Australia is all about. We ignore the so‐called race debate at our peril. I urge all honourable senators to support Senator Kernot's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this motion. In doing so, I would just like to refer to a couple of articles in today's press. You can find on almost a daily basis in the press around Australia an indication of the need for a process of reconciliation in which facts can be put before the Australian people rather than the fiction which is constantly peddled. This never ceases to be important. I am talking about a story from the Adelaide Advertiser that all honourable senators will find in today's Senate clips and it is in the Herald‐Sun and various other papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Because Senator Alston is in the chamber at the moment, I might just mention in respect to these stories—they are, of course, all written by the same journalist—the constant concern in Australia with the concentration of media ownership in this country. I got some real evidence the other day of the difficulties that are caused by our unfortunately bad situation in Australia with concentration of ownership.

I received a letter that had been circulated, I presume to all members of parliament from News Ltd, extolling the virtues of new arrangements that they had just entered into that would provide nomination of a number of specialist journalists to particular areas of reporting which would result in a better quality, more accurate, and so on, news service for Australians. They pointed out—it made my hair stand up to see it in black and white—that this one organisation, News Ltd, is responsible for `70 per cent of the print media which Australians read on a daily basis'. That attracted my attention, and I am sure Senator Alston got a copy of the same letter as we all did. The letter was simply advising us of these new arrangements and boasting about the fact that News Ltd had 70 per cent of the coverage of the morning news that Australians sit down and read.

That is a very good thing if all the stories that News Ltd prints are accurate. But it is very disturbing when you discover gross inaccuracies in stories written about Aboriginal affairs—I have pointed out some of these in earlier debate in this chamber—knowing that those stories are simultaneously being read by 70 per cent of Australians that are reading morning newspapers. That places a significant responsibility on the people who enjoy this kind of monopoly in this country to ensure that their coverage is not in any way biased and is accurate.

In this respect, I see in today's papers a banner headline that reads `ATSIC bosses' windfall'. It talks about pay rises that have been received by executives of ATSIC. This often happens in newspaper reports. If I had to list one significant whinge about newspapers in 20 years in public life, misleading headlines would be at the top of the list. When you read the body of the report, it accurately points out that the ATSIC bosses' windfall is precisely the same windfall that every other public servant in a similar position received across the board.

It also points out accurately that these remuneration levels are set across all government departments by the Remuneration Tribunal. This is all carried in the body of the story itself. It also points out—and I was intrigued to see this—that the ATSIC bosses get more than their minister. Well, hold the front page! Hold the back page, more like. In my seven years as a minister in all the portfolios that I was in, I was never in a position where I earned as much as any one of the people who were in fact employed in statutory authorities responsible to me. In fact, I can recall that the chief executive of the smallest organisation for which I had carriage—and it is a very small organisation and there is no need to name it—was then earning $180,000 a year, which was commensurate with the same positions held by executives in other statutory authorities. In fact, that was about double what I then earned.

I point out that that is a commonplace situation, because the fact is that most of us are not in it for the money. We are in it for other things and job satisfaction has a lot to do with it. It is commonplace for statutory officers in every single statutory authority that a minister is responsible for to be earning significantly more than the minister. So what? But this is highlighted as some dreadful crime being committed by ATSIC and that it is uniquely ATSIC bosses' windfall. It then goes on to talk about Pat Turner and I found this grossly offensive in personal terms. It says:
ATSIC's latest annual report reveals the chief executive, Ms Patricia Turner, a niece of former ATSIC deputy chairman Mr Charles Perkins, tops the payroll.

On this occasion that is an absolutely clear and sleazy inference in that paragraph that Pat Turner got that job because of preferment, nepotism and her relationship with Charles Perkins. If that was Sue Smith or someone I did not know, I would read that and say, `Perhaps that is right. Perhaps it is wrong.'

I am sure the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) would be the first one to agree with me on this, but anyone who even knows Patricia Turner slightly—and perhaps you could ask some of the people she worked with when she worked for Prime Minister and Cabinet in an equally senior position—knows full well that Pat Turner got that job purely on personal merit and nothing else. In fact I know that Pat Turner was approached on many occasions over a period of years to take the chief executive's position at ATSIC and declined to do so because she deliberately wanted to broaden her experience in other Commonwealth government departments. In fact, she is a public servant of significant ability and has got her position, as everyone who knows her knows, through nothing else except her own ability. This is today's press and you constantly read this kind of sleaze and inference.

TALK.START.PARA: —It even made the Hobart Mercury.

—There you go, and that is what I get angry about. I know that the newspaper group that publishes this sleaze—to quote its own letter to me—provides 70 per cent of the total readership for morning news in Australia. I want to say on the public record here in the Senate that this inference is wrong. Pat Turner did not get her senior position with ATSIC because of any relationship with Charles Perkins or family connections. In fact, she rejected—and I know this to be a fact—approaches for years to take the job until she felt that she was ready for it because she wanted to broaden her experience in other departments. I know that she is a bureaucrat who is held in high regard in the Commonwealth Public Service. This is the sort of nonsense perpetuated on a daily basis which makes the work of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation absolutely crucial.

SPEECH.PARA: We were talking earlier in the session about leadership being required on these things in order to get the correct picture through to Australians and about the role the Prime Minister has played in that with his comments for example about the `Aboriginal industry'. I was profoundly disheartened when I heard the Prime Minister say it. As I pointed out at the time, the only two people of whom I was aware who had used that totally pejorative expression `Aboriginal industry' in the last several years were the honourable member for Oxley, Pauline Hanson, who used it in a column she wrote to the Bulletin, and the Prime Minister of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Margaret Valadian.

—Perhaps others as well whom I did not notice. It is a totally pejorative term. The Prime Minister made public statements in respect of the honourable member for Oxley's contribution about Australia being overrun by Asians and so on. To quote the Prime Minister again, he said that many of the things she said were `an accurate reflection of what people feel'—that is people generally, all people—and I rejected that. Comments were made at the time correctly that, where the Prime Minister has failed in this debate, is that he has been talking in code and that is a fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I was reminded of a biography I read years ago on a very well known character in terms of race debates in the United States, and that was the former Governor of Alabama, George Wallace. It triggered a memory for me and I have just finished re‐reading the biography. It is a fascinating biography. There is a particular section of the biography that I recall from years ago which just nails this stuff down. Everyone knows what they are talking about. This book is written by a southern journalist called Marshall Frady.

What prompted this memory was an absolutely superb television production broadcast by the ABC in Australia last week on the American presidential election and Dole and Clinton. It was heartening to see that kind of in‐depth, quality television being produced once again by the public television organisations in the United States. They are the same organisations which produced that magnificent civil war series. If honourable senators did not see the Dole/Clinton production last week that I am talking about, they should do themselves a favour and have a look at it. It was superb.
One of the journalists that was a commentator in that program was indeed the same Marshall Frady, the author of this biography of Wallace. On page 6 of this biography, he says:
To many he portends the eventual arrival of a final racist psychology—
this is George Wallace—

into American politics. It seems certain that his candidacy can only increase the racial alienation in the country. A moderate Alabama politician declares, "What he's trying to do in the nation is what he's managed to do in Alabama. When you draw the line the way he does, the whites go with the white, and the blacks with the black, and when that happens, you're in for warfare." A former Alabama senator echoes, "It's conceivable that he could win a state like Illinois or even California when he puts that hay down where the goats can get at it. He can use all the other issues—law and order, running your own schools, protecting property rights—and never mention race. But people will know he's telling them, `A nigger's trying to get your job, trying to move into your neighbourhood.' What Wallace is doing is talking to them in a kind of shorthand, a kind of code.

That is absolutely correct. That is what we have seen during these very disturbed several months in Australia, to the great concern of us all. I have seen nothing like it in the 20 years that I have been in public life and it is about time it was put down.

I commend the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs for the position he took on this on the Sunday program. I thought his statements were forthright and helpful to this debate. But I express my great regret again about the comment last week by the Prime Minister of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I understood that Senator Collins was going to speak for five minutes.
—You should have rejected that theory when you heard it.
—I am told that we can always accept what the opposition says in its detailed form.
—There is no point of order but if there were an agreement, maybe you could assist the Senate, Senator Collins.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I will conclude, having been brought to order by Senator Hill. I do deeply regret the kind of unmistakable code in which the Prime Minister is speaking—the same sort of code that George Wallace's biographer, Marshall Frady referred to. No‐one is in any doubt about what the Prime Minister means when he talks about not having a `black armband' approach to Australian history. These remarks are unfortunate. It is about time that the Prime Minister delivered the same forthright advocacy on behalf of Aboriginal Australia that I saw on the Sunday program from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by drawing the attention of all honourable senators—and I will not quote it because of the time—to the introductory paragraph on page 1 of the annual report of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, which mentions that despite the problems of ignorance and apathy in respect of the real position with Aboriginal funding and so on, there is `widespread community support for reconciliation'. I believe, fundamentally, that that is the case and that is why it is even more important that the work of this council is fully supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, can you rule that the motion be divided into its parts because of its complexity?
—I have been advised that a motion can be divided at the request of any senator. The question is whether you want them all taken separately.

—Yes, I want them taken separately. We are happy to vote in support of (a) and (c) but we cannot vote for (b) because, as Senator Troeth said in her presentation, we do not believe that it accurately reflects the funding situation.
—Are you moving to put (a), (b) and (c) separately?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to sum up first before you put the motion, Madam Acting Deputy President, whether it is separately or collectively. The Senate should pass parts (a), (b) and (c) of this motion. I am hopeful that when we have the vote on part (b), the majority of the Senate will pass that anyway; but we should pass it for a couple of reasons. We should pass it in the context of the recent resolution of the parliament, particularly the third dot point which says:

SPEECH.PARA: `reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage';

Senator Troeth says that the government objects to part (b) of my motion and has put before us what she says are facts which support the government's assertions that they are increasing funding for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and that, through various other programs, there is an overall increase in the indigenous issues budget.

When you cut everything by 20 per cent across the board it is very easy then to say, `But next year you are getting an increase.' When you are rolling over something into the next budget it is very easy to say, `You are getting an increase.' The fact of the matter is the budgets were cut by 20 per cent. In the case of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, the cuts have reduced its staff and severely reduced its capacity to carry forward its work for the remainder of its term. That is the reality.

The Senate should pass this motion because there is a special case to be made for the work of ATSIC and the work of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in furthering this parliament's reaffirmation of its commitment to reconciliation. That is why ATSIC and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation should have been a special case when budget cuts were being considered.

Of course, ATSIC and the council are not immune from scrutiny. No‐one is saying that. This motion is simply saying that you cannot one week pass a resolution saying we reaffirm our commitment, allow yourself to feel good about it and do nothing about the actions which make it possible for that resolution to be implemented.

The second reason we should pass this motion is that the Senate and the individual members of it should take their opportunity to continue to speak out in the face of the continuing ill‐informed and racist comments of the member for Oxley and certain media commentators. We have an obligation to do that and I thank those who have taken part in this debate for being willing to take this opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion put by Senator Kernot in its (a) (b) and (c) form be agreed to. Given that Senator Hill has asked that it be divided, I now put the question: that paragraph (a) as moved by Senator Kernot be agreed to. I think the ayes have it. The question is: that paragraph (b) as moved by Senator Kernot be agreed to. I think the ayes have it. The question is: that paragraph (c) moved by Senator Kernot be agreed to. I think the ayes have it.
—I ask that general business notice of motion No. 311 standing in my name for today and relating to the member for Oxley, Ms Hanson, be taken as a formal motion.
—Is there any objection to that notice of motion being taken as formal?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 311.

At the outset, I thank Senator Margetts for that refusal to give formality. I had had refusal to give formality flagged to me from the government, but then the government was withdrawing that commitment from yesterday to try to stifle debate on this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Well, we will at least have this debate. Last week in this parliament there was unanimity for a motion which comprehensively reaffirmed this nation's tolerance, its diversity, its multiculturalism and its sense of a fair go. The initiative for that historic motion, however, did not come from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard); it came from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and a Liberal MP.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it was a turning point against the outbreak of racism which followed the first speech of Pauline Hanson in the House of Representatives. One can see the impact of that motion by referring to comments from the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Chris Sidoti, on the weekend. He was commenting on the furore that has followed the racist and bigoted statements of Ms Hanson in saying:

This is perhaps a new industry that we are seeing develop in Australia—the manipulation industry that tries to attract some points of advantage from the misuse of different phrases, different words, to dignify it with the word `debate'. What we have had and what we have experienced in the last few months is a gross misstatement of what has occurred. What has occurred is an outbreak of racism. There has been no fact and no logic in what many of the people who have dragged this so‐called debate into the community and inflicted on us have had to say.

He went on to add that since that motion went through this parliament, whereas the majority of calls to the Human Rights Commission had been abusive, and supporting the comments of Ms Hanson, there had been a turnaround and those comments are running seven to one against what she has had to say. There is the value of leadership. There is the failure of our Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Unless I am mightily mistaken, we are debating the suspension and urgency for suspension and I have not even heard the word `urgency'. If Senator Brown wants to suspend standing orders, he could at least tell us why we should deal with such an urgent matter.

—Senator Panizza, I thank you for your comments. It is always a fine line to decide between what is the substance of the debate about a matter for urgency and what is the substance of debate. I draw those comments to your attention, Senator Brown.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I take the point. This matter is urgent. Senator Panizza knows that this is urgent. And it is the failure of the Prime Minister that we now have to urgently address because every day we are getting more stories, more indications, more implications, from the racist fire that has been fanned not only by Ms Hanson but by the failure of the Prime Minister as the leader of this nation to tackle her head‐on and to rebut her misinformation and her bigotry head‐on.

SPEECH.PARA: Pauline Hanson has shown a weakness in compassion. She has shown a failure to relate to others. Her shortcomings are as a tense and immature person without much worldly wisdom. It was easy to spot that, and it would have been easy for the leader of this country to recognise that her arguments could very easily be rebutted but that unrebutted they could cause great damage in our society. And that is what has happened.

It was the Prime Minister's failure of leadership, as much as anything, which has led to the need for an urgent call from this Senate for him now to take the tack he should have taken at the outset. The failure of the Prime Minister has never been more demonstrated than by his failure to come off the verge, get into the traffic of this debate and redivert it.

Just a few weeks ago, Pauline Hanson visited an Aboriginal community in Queensland. Instead of feeling sorrow for the forced cultural dislocation and disintegration, for the years of oppression, for the intolerable unemployment, which is such a potent force in what we are seeing, and for the health statistics—including Aboriginal infant mortality—all she saw were papers blowing in the breeze; all she saw were papers on the verge. It is the Prime Minister standing on that verge that is the problem we are facing today. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand on behalf of the government to oppose the suspension of standing orders. This is grandstanding by Senator Brown—presumably to some constituency—brought on by a somewhat devious manoeuvre on the part of the Greens. The time for debate on this matter was last week when it was debated, generally speaking in a sensible and rational way, after which the parliament passed a resolution—across the parliament—to reinforce the standards that the vast majority of Australians apply to themselves and expect to be applied by representatives in this chamber. That was the occasion to pass such a resolution.

BREAK.PARA: The motion was passed and there is now an attempt to revive it by Senator Brown for no reason other than that he believes it can be to his short-term political advantage. No attempt has been made by him to establish urgency for this debate. It is therefore an abuse of these processes. It is simply Senator Brown seeking to attack the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and I would be quite happy to stand the credentials of the Prime Minister on this matter against those of Senator Brown any day. The Prime Minister has condemned and continues to condemn racism and bigotry in all its forms, but what he does not have to do is jump to the demands of Senator Brown.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sympathy for the substance of the motion, and I did say in the debate last week that I felt we did not go far enough in the agreed resolution. But I do not have sympathy for the device that is being used to bring this on as a matter of urgency. Quite frankly, I was surprised when I was given suspension of standing orders to debate the motion that I put forward for the same reason. I think what made my motion a little more urgent were this morning's comments of Alan Jones on the radio and the continuing attack on ATSIC and the need to speak up today on that matter. So, while I regret the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) did not take on Pauline Hanson, the member for Oxley, at the beginning in a more obvious way by rebutting the fallacious and bigoted statements that she is making, I do not agree that it is urgent to do that now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make the position of the opposition absolutely clear on the substantive motion of Senator Brown, No. 311. Last Wednesday, we had a situation in the parliament where both houses of the parliament engaged in what I described as an historic debate. It was a debate on the kind of society we are and the kind of society that we aspire to be: a decent, tolerant, pluralistic society; a society that is free of racism.

SPEECH.PARA: That debate was a direct response to the divisive and dangerous community reaction to the sorts of intolerant views, the stridency and the ignorance of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). In that debate, the motion was passed unanimously by both houses of parliament. It provided national leadership on an issue of vital national importance. I must say that the opposition has clearly said it shares the sentiments that that leadership has been found wanting in the lukewarm and ambivalent responses of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this issue. That debate provided an opportunity, though, for all parties represented in the parliament to express their views on this issue. There was a further opportunity this morning through the vehicle of the motion moved by Senator Kernot.

The substantive motion that Senator Brown wants to bring on is one that the Labor Party will support. We do support this substantive motion. But I also want to say this: in this chamber a few moments ago, we saw a trick from Senator Brown, as has been exposed by Senator Hill and Senator Kernot, and a trick from Senator Margetts. Senator Brown, in his substantive motion, asks for formality and Senator Margetts says, `No. I, Senator Margetts'—Senator Brown's comrade in arms; the other Green senator—`will not agree to formality.' That, I am afraid, Senator Brown, is just not acceptable practice in this place.

I have never known a political party in this place to think a motion is of significance but then have that motion formality opposed by a member of the same party. It has not happened from the Labor Party since I have been a member of the Senate; I do not believe it has happened with the coalition; I do not believe it has happened with the Australian Democrats. I want to say to you, Senator Brown: it has never happened before with the Australian Greens. It is a trick. It is a crude parliamentary device that I think you will regret.

I make it clear to you that we will support absolutely the substantive motion you move. Don't be under any misapprehension about that. But also, Senator Brown, don't come into this chamber and use those sorts of devices, those sorts of tricks, those sorts of abuses of parliamentary privilege and expect a party like the Australian Labor Party, which has always had a fine record of defending proper parliamentary process in this and other chambers, to support it. We will not do that, Senator Brown.So while I am happy to place on record our strong support for your motion, the sentiments behind your motion and many of the comments you have made in support of your motion, I will not support the use of this sort of device now or on other occasions. I am disappointed that you have resorted to that.

Let me make it clear that we will take any invitation that is offered to the opposition to denounce racial intolerance in any form. I believe we need in this parliament to respond to the call of the Australian community for strong and unequivocal leadership from our parliamentary representatives on this issue. The Labor Party will always respond to that. But we will never respond to these sorts of parliamentary tricks. On that basis, I assure you, Senator Brown and Senator Margetts, we will not support the motion for the suspension of standing orders manipulated in such a way by the two Australian Greens senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be one small point that Senator Faulkner has missed here. We are not actually from the same party. The Australian Greens and the Greens (WA) are different parties.
—Oh!

—No, I want to put that on the record. Senator Faulkner has actually given an incorrect statement. `The two Australian Greens senators' is an incorrect statement. I am with a separate party, the Greens (WA). Senator Bob Brown is with the Australian Greens.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, if the Senate wants to listen to the basis for my action in relation to both today and yesterday, it is because if there has ever been a convention that has been manipulated or ratted upon, it is that in the last few weeks what we have seen is a change of convention, whereby parties who disagree with a motion are saying that it should be a formal motion—that is, indicating that they agree with the motion—and then voting against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get formality and try us out. That's rubbish.
—Senator Collins does not want to hear this debated but if we are talking about proper process—
—If it had got formality we would have voted for it.
—Let us give Senator Margetts a fair go here.
—Would you have voted for it?
—Senator Alston, Senator Margetts has the call.

—If we are talking about proper process and about what is and should be the proper process in this Senate, it is about whether or not the device of leading the Senate in one direction in terms of declaring formality in order simply to gag debate is good process. For the purpose of process, to allow a debate to occur which is important is to say that the question is whether this should be without debate or not. That is what the process of formality is about.

BREAK.PARA: By denying formality, as Senator Harradine did on a previous occasion, it is saying the debate should occur, the people in the Senate should listen to the ideas before we knew what everybody knew, which is that both major parties had various opinions. The government said no; instead of denying debate, you have the process to listen to those debates.

If we are talking about process, it is time the government stopped using that device to gag debate and realised that people do have the right to speak on important issues in the Senate. I certainly have different viewpoints on the issue of the handling of the race debate from Senator Brown. People heard my passionate contribution to last week's debate. If you have not read it, I advise people to look at what I said in that debate.

My viewpoint is that we will never in our community be able to deal with this urgent issue until we look at the means by which a growing number of people in our community are becoming disillusioned. And yes, I also believe it is absolutely necessary and urgent for the leader of the government in Australia to rebut the misinformation that has been provided to the community.

I may have a different viewpoint from Senator Brown in relation to how that might be done, but I do not think it is proper process to do what the government has been doing in recent times, which has been to gag debate. Quite frankly, this is probably a convenient means by which the opposition can avoid dealing with the issue, by saying, `We are shocked and horrified by the contravention of the process' when they have been involved in complicity in recent weeks in subverting that process themselves in gagging debate.

So if we are going to talk about process, let us go back to the beginning of what motions are about, what formality is about. If I have subverted the process, let us talk about how that process is being subverted at the moment by parties together guaranteeing formality in order simply to gag debate, by saying, `Yes, we agree with formality but no, we won't allow any debate on this issue.' So process is important. Let us talk about process, before we start flinging outrageous arrows, and about what we should be doing in this place to look at rights of speech. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is taken from Senator Margetts because some time last week there was a call for a division by Senator Brown and Senator Margetts was here. Of course, you need two persons to call for a division to take place. On that occasion Senator Brown's was the only voice calling for a division, so I think that proves what Senator Margetts has been saying, that they are not in fact the same party.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to raise goes to the question of, I suppose, courtesy and form in this place. Over the 21 years that I have been here, one soon finds out—it takes some of us longer to find out—that one does not contribute to the general debate in the community or to the legislative improvement of our Commonwealth enactments, or indeed to the sort of country that we are looking to improve by our actions here, by rubbing people up the wrong way. Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, with due respect to Senator Brown, I would like to say that what he is doing here now is really something that he has been doing for the last three, four or five weeks: in essence, he is trying to jump the queue.

There are a large number of notices of motion on the Notice Paper. What is happening here, as has happened on a number of previous occasions—through you, Madam Acting Deputy President to Senator Brown—is that there is a call of formality. On a number of occasions that has been agreed to; on other occasions there has been a call of non‐formal. But bear in mind that other senators have notices of motion they would like to see dealt with by this chamber.

Under standing order 66 there is provision, if the notice of motion is called formal, for the notice of motion to be put without debate. Generally that occurs after there has been discussion between people in the chamber and people have been given time to consider the implications of voting on a matter without debate. That is a special procedure that I believe is allowed for under standing orders, but it relies on the goodwill of every one of the 76 senators here. It is obvious, Senator Brown, that the goodwill is running out. I hope that you will take this on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at your own history of goodwill, Senator Harradine, before you make too many comments on that line.

—I am not sure what that means; perhaps you should let the Senate know. I think you have to understand that you need the goodwill of every single senator to pursue the avenues outlined in standing order 66. For that reason I feel that I will be voting against a suspension of standing orders. But there is another reason. Today I think we gave the member for Oxley a pretty strong serve in the motion put forward by Senator Kernot which was adopted—(Time expired)

—Before I call the vote on this suspension motion, I would simply like to inform the Senate—and perhaps correct a misunderstanding of yours, Senator Margetts—that while declaring a motion formal means that there is no time allowed for debate, it does not mean senators may not vote against it. That needs to be clearly understood. Perhaps today's contribution indicates the old Kermit adage that it's not easy being green.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I don't think that comment is appropriate for the position you are in.
—It wasn't insulting; it was humorous. Haven't the Greens got a sense of humour?
—I have, but not—
—Would you resume your seat, please, Senator? You can take this up in another way, Senator. I will now put the motion for or against the suspension of standing orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendment made by the Senate to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert
