DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK ZONING PLANS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Cairns Section Zoning Plan (Amendment No. 1 of 1996), the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Central Section Zoning Plan (Amendment No. 1 of 1996) and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Mackay/Capricorn Section Zoning Plan (Amendment No. 1 of 1996), made under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, be disallowed.

This motion relates to the disallowance of regulations that will open up currently protected areas of the Great Barrier Reef to fishing. We move the disallowance of this regulation because we believe that, rather than reduce the amount of the Great Barrier Reef that is protected, we should be looking to other examples, such as forestry, where we see some 15 per cent of various forest types being protected. Rather than tapping now into the just over four per cent of the reef that is protected, we should be increasing the amount of reef protected to closer to 15 per cent.

Let us look at this issue that is before us today. Many Australians believe that the entire reef is protected. It is a view that is widespread but, unfortunately, very little of it is. It is opened up to a range of resource extraction activities, in particular, fishing. That is a major means of extracting resources on that reef and, indeed, the major way in which the resources of the reef are depleted. It is rather ironic that so little of our marine species on the reef are protected, because this is what the majority of tourists go to see. This is what attracts the tourists and earns the huge amount of money that is being earned by the tourism industry in Queensland.

It is the beauty and the abundance and diversity of marine life that draw people to the reef itself. One of the major reasons it is now listed as a world heritage area is its abundance and diversity. The other 96 per cent of the reef is open to a range of activities, including trawling, commercial and recreational line fishing, diving, et cetera.

It is already considered that there are areas of the reef that are over‐fished. This is and has been recognised for some time as a major problem. However, instead of protecting more of the reef from the damaging effects of fishing, the Cooperative Research Centre for the Great Barrier Reef and GBRMPA want to open up some of the protected zones to fish target species and then see what happens. The experiment is designed to take about 24 reefs—16 of them in protected zones—and fish target species, then close the reefs for a few years to see what comes back and how biodiversity is affected. That is akin to opening up some of our national parks, shooting out maybe black cockatoos, lining up the carcasses to count how many there are and then sitting back and waiting to see how many of that species find their way back into that particular forest area.

While the minister will undoubtedly use arguments that there are still some protected areas left, that this experiment is not going to go into all the protected areas, I think he will forget to tell us what the evidence is of the actual impact of this activity on the reef. I think he will conveniently avoid mentioning the fact that there will be more impacts on some areas than others.

For example, in the central zone of the barrier reef there are only 32 protected zones. Yet he seeks to allow eight of those to be used in this experiment; that is one in four areas on that reef. Nowhere is there an assumption that most of the reefs once had the fish that are now to be found in these protected areas and then use that basis as a means of comparing what has happened in other parts of the reef.

I am not quite sure, but it seems that there are some scientists out there who actually cannot count fish that are swimming. They have actually got to kill them and line them up and then see how many of the species were out there. Nowhere is there an assumption that closing off fished areas, waiting to see what comes back and comparing that to protected zones in two years would also give the result without opening up these protected areas.

Nowhere is there an assumption that the computer modelling, which has already been done and is based on an earlier experiment, is sufficient to at least give a very accurate idea of exactly what is going to happen rather than going out and plundering these areas of reef. The government has an act to protect the reef and the intent of that act has not changed.

PARA.BREAK: Moss Cass said in a second reading speech to this parliament that the Australian govern ment `has decided the protection of our unique Barrier Reef is of paramount importance to Australia and the world'. Since the Great Barrier Reef act was enacted, the only thing that has really changed is that there is now the overlay of the World Heritage Act, which has the primary aim of protection, conservation and preservation of the reef to transmit those values to future generations. It is based on the ethic of the precautionary principle, which in no way could be stretched to allow these experiments to go ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Democrats put through two significant amendments to the Great Barrier Reef act to include the precautionary principle also in management plans and to have the concept of world heritage put into that act. We have two acts affecting this area and the precautionary principle is in both of them. Yet still the authority and the Cooperative Research Centre are persisting with this reef line fishing experiment which goes against the precautionary principle.

Last year GBRMPA stopped their anchor damage experiment. They were going to deliberately destroy reefs to look at the effect of anchor damage instead of monitoring the reefs that had already been affected by anchor damage and looking at the impact on species and what was happening on those reefs. Where is the consistency in opening up protected areas of the reef to fishing and fishing out as much as they can target species. They have already done this experiment.

I point to the example of Bramble Reef, which was closed to fishing for about 3½ years. It was reopened and within several weeks 80 per cent of its adult fish were taken by the industry. I could go through the documents that Senator Hill has presented to us. They are able to do their computer modelling on that experiment. They know what is going to happen. They know what was left. They are already making some suggestions on what the results of this experiment that they are arguing they absolutely have to do are going to be.

There certainly are a few scientists within GBRMPA that support this experiment. Unfortunately, many of those who think the experiment should not go ahead have not been listened to. Proper process has not been followed by the environment minister. I do not believe we should let these regulations through this place because, firstly, proper process has not been followed and, secondly, we should be conserving, not experimenting with, what little of the Great Barrier Reef is protected.

The environment minister, as you know, is required to take a number of steps to gather advice before making or allowing Commonwealth decisions which will significantly affect the environment. Yet on 17 October he tabled regulations to downsize some of the few protected areas of the reef to allow fishing. He tabled and expects the parliament to allow these regulations without ever examining reasonable and prudent alternatives, without asking the Heritage Commission for advice and without ever receiving and considering such advice. He has also not made a decision about designating the proposal and whether or not to have any environmental review proposal under the EP(IP) Act.

Now it appears the minister will argue that he still could ask for some of this advice after the rezonings have been through this place—that is, before the advertisement goes in the paper notifying that the rezoning has occurred. Technically there may possibly be room for this to happen, but surely this is a farcical approach to decision making. He has made his decisions on the rezoning to allow the experiments without due process or proper advice as he is required to do. If we let these regulations through today we will not have another chance to debate them.

The Democrats have received a copy of a letter from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to the Australian Heritage Commission demonstrating that correct process has, in their words, been `unfortunately overlooked and a slip has occurred'. It also sets out the minister's argument that he could wait until the end of the process to begin the process. This is like something I remember from Alice in Wonderland where the Queen said, `We always do it like this—verdict first and evidence later.' I have circulated to a number of senators the advice I have received from the clerks on the letter, the legislation and the minister's arguments. Senators can see for themselves that the opinion of the clerks tallies with our opinion and they support what we are saying.

The Democrats argue strongly that this advice provides a clear argument that these regulations have to be disallowed today. This particular form of regulation cannot simply be deferred. Only by disallowing can the parliament be assured that the minister made an informed and proper decision before putting the regulations before us. The minister could come back in six months after following this process and do the same thing. I notice that the minister is already talking about some revision of the body that oversees the Great Barrier Reef. What is the point in letting through things like this major reef experiment and then reviewing the body that has let this slip through its net?

I will turn to the second reason for disallowance which is the science of this issue. It does not appear that the idea of conservation has got through to this government. Conservation means you look after something, protect it and do not start eating into the few areas that you have actually protected.

Conservation is not about hanging onto something for a while, then gradually downsizing the area you have protected bit by bit. To say that we have to kill fish in protected areas to count them is like that old argument Japan has been using about having to kill whales to count them. That is an argument that Australia has found abhorrent. Hopefully Japan and Norway are now moving away from those scientific experiments.

I must remind the Senate that this is also a world heritage area. Under that act we should be using the precautionary principle. We should be observing that principle and using a totally different methodology from the one that these scientists are suggesting. Obviously we have to know about fishing pressures on the reef, but there are other ways of doing it.

Finally, letting industry into a protected area, even if it is only for a few years, is a very dangerous precedent to set. Why not close some of the 96 per cent of the reef that is currently open for various periods of time, put different fishing pressures on them, let line fishing and commercial fishing in and see some of the impacts there rather than open up these few protected areas? Surely at the very least we should have before this chamber more time to look at some of the very difficult issues we are facing in regard to the very small amount of reef that is protected. As I said before, less than five per cent of forest areas are protected.

What if the industry minister does not accept the results and asks for more time? Where are we going to draw the line in the sand? The Democrats argue that it should be drawn now, that there are compelling reasons, both because due process has not been followed and for conservation reasons, why we should not pass these regulations.

I stress again that we want the minister to follow his own legislation before making such decisions. Indeed, if the regulations are not disallowed we will have no further opportunity in this place to debate this issue. There will be no point in waiting for any review that the minister might put in place of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. There will not be any time to revisit the issue of line fishing.

If they are disallowed, the minister still has the opportunity to follow the processes and then, in six months, he can present these regulations to us. I acknowledge those senators who have indicated that they are supporting us on this. I hope that other senators will move with us today to protect the Great Barrier Reef and, indeed, to protect one of Australia's 11 world heritage areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what this debate is all about—what is the best course of action to protect the reef and its conservation values. In this instance we are particularly talking about the fish resource of the reef. There is no debate about what we are seeking to achieve. The debate is about whether the advice that is being put to the authority by Australia's best marine scientists as essential to ensure that there is not overfishing of the reef to the extent that it would threaten the resource should be accepted.

PARA.BREAK: I have some sympathy, as I said in question time a few days ago, with the sort of instinc tive reaction of Senator Lees, which was not dissimilar to my own reaction when I first read these papers. I wondered why it was necessary to open currently closed reefs to produce data that was essential to assure us that we were not overfishing the currently open reefs. As I said in question time, I was sufficiently concerned to sit down personally with the scientists in Townsville. Even after listening to their argument and debating it with them I still went back and sought further information from them because I felt that I had to be satisfied that, although years of planning have gone into this experiment, it was well based.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not easy for a non-marine scientist to do. If you cannot turn to the experts for advice in relation to specialised areas, where do you turn? We all start with our instincts and our prejudices but most of us, if it is an area of specialisation beyond our training or experience, then turn to the experts and listen to their arguments. We probe them and we test them. As I did in this instance, if necessary we revisit it several times. But in revisiting it they constantly came back with the argument that they could not be confident that the current fishing regime was not putting stocks at risk unless they were able to compare the resource with an area that was not currently fished. Only with that would they have sufficient data to be confident that the conservation regime that is in place for the reefs that are being fished was such that it would preserve the stock.

When they come back and are reinforced by their professional colleagues in this assessment it is very difficult to decide otherwise. In fact, my judgment in the end was that it would be reckless of me to put my non-specialised assessment ahead of the specialists who told me that, unless this experiment was carried out, the stocks would be threatened.

The experimentation is to ensure that the conservation regime is adequate and is working. My agreement to the experimentation is therefore precautionary, Senator. You said that the precautionary principle should apply. But it would have been disregarding the precautionary principle if I disregarded the advice of the scientists and said, `You are not going to carry out this experiment and I will take a chance that the current conservation regime, against your judgment and your advice, will work.'

I can imagine the uproar in this place in a few years time—if perchance I was still the environment minister—if the stocks had collapsed on the reefs that were open and I stood up and tried to justify why I had not taken the advice of the scientific experts and enabled them to carry out the experimentation which they had said was necessary to be satisfied that the conservation regime in place was working. Senator, they tell me and they tell you that the history of fishing on reefs internationally—and fishing generally—is that stocks collapse quickly and often with very little evidence that it is going to occur. At times it happens so quickly that it is too late to then change the conservation regime and preserve the resource. That is the fear that some Australian scientists have expressed to me on this matter. In those circumstances, the precautionary step for me to take is to accept their advice.

Senator Lees, I know that you are sitting over there and saying all the scientists are wrong. But I do not think that I am in a position where I can responsibly make that judgment. A lot of these scientists—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's good to know that you know more than the scientists—not you, Senator Hill.
—It is not as if this is something that has been thought up in the last week or two. The planning for this research and establishing the basis of the research has been taking place for some years.
—Why do you think they are doing it?

—I do not know many of these scientists, I have to concede. But I was interested in a press release that was put out in response to a press release of Senator Meg Lees on 30 October. This was put out by Dr Alan Butler, whom I do know. He put this out as President of the Australian Marine Sciences Association. I do not think he has any interest in this experiment, but I am not absolutely sure of that. I am sure Senator Lees will tell me if I am wrong. The press release read:

SPEECH.PARA: "If we are to protect the Reef, we must understand how it works. That means we have to understand how the fish respond when fishing activities are carried on," Dr Butler said.
"The series of experiments criticised by Senator Lees are an absolutely central tool in the process of gaining scientific knowledge."
"There are good and bad ways of designing experiments, and there must be no confusion about the difference. Poorly designed experiments lead to unreliable knowledge."
Dr Butler said that the Reef research process had been thoroughly discussed by competent scientists at both national and international level.

"Senator Lees' emotive claims that the experiments would "rip the heart" out of sections of the Reef are simply not true. The scientists involved in this project are vitally concerned about the long‐term future of the Reef," he said.
He criticised the experimental suggestions put forward by the Democrats, saying they would NOT yield the same understanding as the properly planned opening of some reefs and closing of others.

In supporting these experiments, which require a rezoning of portions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, AMSA sees Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GRBMPA) as acting in the best interests of protecting and managing the Reef, and not merely acting for the fishing industry.

Senator Lees came into the Senate the other day and said, `Why are you doing this for the fishing industry?' And I told her, although she disregards it, that I have witnessed correspondence from the fishing industry complaining about what we are doing. Why are they complaining? I will tell you why they are complaining. They are complaining because it means that for some years their resource will be less.

To conduct this experiment, eight reefs that are currently closed—and I understand that is eight out of some 500 reefs that are currently closed—would be open for one year. But, on the other side of the ledger, eight reefs that are currently open would be closed for five years. It is not as if the stock is captured within one reef, so it logically follows that over that period of time the fishing industry would have to accept a reduced take.

BREAK.PARA: They will accept that, Senator Macdonald, because they are obviously interested commercially in ensuring that the resource does not collapse. They are interested in maintaining a resource for commercial reasons. They, like all other Australians, are also interested in preserving the conservation values of the reef.

They are prepared to cooperate with scientists to demonstrate that the conservation regime at the moment is working satisfactorily in terms of protecting a resource or, if it is demonstrated that it is not, the conservation regime would have to change. Not only do you have the scientists involved in the experiment—from James Cook University, from the CRC and AIMS—the Australian Institute of Marine Science—up at Townsville all providing us with advice that it is important that this experiment take place to protect the reef values; you have scientists outside of that group, such as Dr Alan Butler, whom I have known for a long time and whom I respect greatly, reinforcing it.

You have the industry prepared to take a drop in stock out of respect for the importance of the experimentations. Yet you have the Democrats and, I think, the Greens coming in here and saying that we should disregard all this advice and take a chance. They say that the precautionary principle is to take a chance. That does not, with respect, make any sense. So I accepted the advice of the scientists after some considerable testing of their argument and that is the reason I have been prepared to agree to these regulations and the rezoning necessary to enable this experimentation to take place.

On the question of process, Mr Deputy President, my legal advice is that the process that I have adopted is perfectly correct. So it is something of a red herring to say that this should fail because there is some error in process. I am not just simply judged by senators in this place. Every action I take has to be in accordance with my obligations, as set out in the various pieces of legislation. I take the best advice to help me ensure that I meet those obligations which are not all straightforward in terms of the legislation under which I operate. The advice I have is that I have acted in accordance with my obligations.

I could go through every step that has been taken by me and also by GBRMPA because we both have separate responsibilities in relation to this particular effort but I think that would unnecessarily take up the time of the Senate. I simply wish to put on record our response to certain queries put by the opposition, in particular by the shadow minister for the environment, Dr Lawrence. She asked us if we would ensure that the Australian Heritage Commission would be formally informed of the proposed action, as required under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, and would be given a reasonable opportunity to consider and comment on its impact. In the response—which I have given to Dr Lawrence—from the chairman of the marine park authority, Dr McPhail has confirmed that he will consider the application of the Australian Heritage Commission Act before any reefs are opened. He advises that he has already informally referred the proposal to the AHC and if the legislative test is triggered, the proposal will be formally referred to the AHC. I would have thought, Senator Lees, that you would accept that as his obligation under that piece of legislation.

Dr Lawrence also asked if formal consideration would be given as to whether to designate the proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Dr McPhail has also confirmed that he will give formal consideration as to whether to designate the proposal under that act. She asked a number of other questions which I also should put on the record because I have not yet heard whether she believes the authority and I have sufficiently answered her concerns. She said that:

In addition, we believe that the status of the area requires, as a minimum, that explicit monitoring mechanisms are in place for the duration of fishing on the green reefs to ensure irreparable damage is not caused.

The response is that monitoring of fish stocks will be undertaken five times per year for the duration of the experiment and more intensely for the first three months following each reef opening. This will provide a reliable measure of what fishing impact has occurred as a safeguard to ensure irreparable damage is not caused. I would have thought that would give some comfort to Senator Lees. Secondly, Dr Lawrence said that she wanted a commitment from the government that, as a matter of urgency, the information obtained from the experiment would be used to develop a proper management strategy for commercial and recreational fishing on the reef.

The reason for adopting such an experimental approach within the specified time frame is the information is vital for the effective management of the impacts of recreational and commercial fishing on the Great Barrier Reef. That is one of the purposes of the experiment which this is all about. The government is committed to ensuring that this information is promptly applied to management strategies for these two fishing sectors.

Thirdly, Dr Lawrence wanted a guarantee that the reefs would be rezoned to their current status at the completion of the experiment. The response is that the provisions relating to the opening and closing of reefs are spelled out in the proposed zoning amendments. The proposed provisions, which deal with fishing on those reefs that are presently closed, provide that only four of the reefs would be open at the one time and that each reef may be open only for a maximum of 12 months.

I said that Dr McPhail had assured me that the authority would commence proceedings to rezone the green reefs at the completion of the experiment which, I think, is exactly what she was seeking. Fourthly, she was seeking an assurance from me that I would report to parliament, at the end of the first year of the experiment, on the preliminary results of fishing the green reefs. I have given her my assurance that, at the end of the first year of research under the experiment, I will table a report containing the preliminary results.

You will see from that, Mr Deputy President, that we have done our best to meet the requirements of the opposition in this matter. I understand why they are wishing to receive these assurances. As I said, within the spirit of this debate, we are all looking towards the best conservation outcome and it is a matter of us being satisfied.
In conclusion, I have decided that the precautionary approach is to accept the advice of the scientists. To do otherwise at this time would be reckless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak on Senator Lees's disallowance motion. I commence my contribution by making three comments which summarise the opposition's approach to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the rezoning of a world heritage area demands closest scrutiny, particularly if the rezoning involves the opening up of previously protected areas to fishing. Secondly, the CRC Reef Research Centre proposed experiment would make an important contribution to our knowledge of the reef's fish stocks and greatly assist the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority develop a proper management plan for fishing on the reef. Thirdly, the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), by not fulfilling his statutory responsibilities in ensuring the environmental impact of the proposal was formally assessed, as is required under the Australian Heritage Commission Act and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, does severely jeopardise the future of this important experiment.

We have heard much of the views of the scientists and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority who have argued that the rezoning of eight green reefs is essential to allow a proper assessment of the impact of line fishing on the Great Barrier Reef. Marine national park B zones or green reefs are used in the proposed experiment to set a baseline from which the state of the fish population on the surrounding open reefs can be gauged. The proposed experiment will also determine how unfished populations react to fishing.

PARA.BREAK: The experiment has in fact been justified on three grounds. It enables the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to measure the size, age and reproductive structure of populations of fish on previously unfished coral reefs in the Great Barrier Reef. This informa tion will allow the authority to gauge how much fishing the reef can sustain. It will also give the marine park authority an indication of the effect of line fishing on the marine park to date.

SPEECH.PARA: The experiment will enable the scientists to determine what annual rate of fishing effort causes a level of change in the fish stocks. It also allows the authority to look into the future to measure how the fish stocks and the fishery will respond to any future increases in fishing effort. By providing important information about how catch rates relate to the number of fish in the water, the experiment will allow reef managers to better interpret changes in catch rates and, hopefully, avoid the errors that have led to many of the world fisheries collapsing.

The scientists claim that the alternative research designs which involve closing and then reopening general use reefs would delay the experiment by some 10 to 12 years and that this would be irresponsible as the data is required urgently to develop a management plan for fishing on the reef. Without an independent assessment of the experiment by the Australian Heritage Commission to assess all the feasible and prudent alternatives, it is difficult for the opposition to properly assess the arguments for and against the two research designs.

There are over 2,700 reefs in the marine park and nearly 500 of those reefs are closed to line fishing. The experiment proposes to open eight of the 500 reefs for 12 months and close eight open reefs for five years. Only four per cent of the reef is zoned marine park B and opening up these green reefs to fishing for 12 months is a very serious matter.

The opposition does believe at a minimum that, given the world heritage status of the area, explicit monitoring mechanisms are in place for the duration of fishing on the green reefs to ensure irreparable damage is not caused. We believe there should be a commitment from the government that, as a matter of urgency, the information obtained from the experiment is used to develop a proper management strategy for commercial and recreational fishing on the reef.

BREAK.PARA: We believe that a guarantee is required that the reefs will be rezoned back to their current status at the completion of the experiment. We require an assurance from the Minister for the Environment that he will report to the parliament at the end of the first year of the experiment to inform the parliament of the preliminary results of fishing the green reefs.

As the minister indicated, the shadow minister for the environment, Dr Lawrence, yesterday wrote to Senator Hill outlining these issues and requesting his assurance that these matters be addressed in due course. I acknowledge the fact that the minister has provided these assurances, firstly, by letter to Dr Lawrence this morning and, secondly, in the chamber during this debate.

In general, the opposition objects to opening up protected areas. I must say, however, that the scientific benefits and the capacity of the knowledge gained to improve the long‐term sustainable management of fishing on the reef could make this temporary rezoning an exception, provided that proper processes are followed by the Minister for the Environment. Regrettably, it appears that the minister has not properly performed his statutory responsibilities and the matter has not yet been independently assessed by the Australian Heritage Commission and evaluated under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a letter relating to this issue under the signature of Mr Peter McGinnity, Director, Planning, of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, that has been communicated from the marine park authority to Dr Michael Mulvaney of the Australian Heritage Commission. In part, this letter says:

Further to our earlier telephone conversation, I am enclosing background material regarding the proposed zoning amendments. Our records confirm your advice that the Australian Heritage Commission has been inadvertently left off the mailing list for the proposed amendments. However, I believe it would be clearly necessary for the Authority to refer to the Heritage Commission a proposal to open an area to fishing prior to publishing a notice (written advertisement) implementing such a proposal. Then the letter goes on:
It is unfortunate that this quite controversial issue has slipped through the system—
these are the words that Senator Lees used earlier—
without our normal process of consultation with the Commission.
Well, it is unfortunate that it slipped through the system. I think most of us would acknowledge that.

In the letter to Senator Hill from Dr Lawrence that Senator Hill referred to, Dr Lawrence stated that the opposition's position on the regulations tabled in the Senate was conditional on a couple of issues. They were: immediate government action to ensure the Australian Heritage Commission is formally informed of the proposed action, as required under the AHC Act, and given reasonable opportunity to consider and comment on its impact; and that it gives formal consideration to whether to designate the proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

Senator Hill indicated a little earlier in the debate what his response was to these two matters in the letter that he sent to Dr Lawrence this morning. He advises me that he has already informally referred the proposal to the Australian Heritage Commission. If the legislative test is triggered then the proposal will be formally referred to the Australian Heritage Commission.
And on the other issue:
Dr McPhail has also confirmed that he will give formal consideration on whether to designate the proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

The position of the opposition on this is that at this stage the minister's response does not go far enough. We believe that the proposal should be formally referred to the Australian Heritage Commission for proper assessment and consideration of prudent and feasible alternatives. We are continuing to demand of the minister that he give that assurance on this matter. I must say to the Senate that, in the absence of a clear assurance on that, we do have very little choice but to support the Democrats' disallowance motion standing in the name of Senator Lees.

I also make the point—and I hope this is acknowledged by the minister—that this exchange of correspondence has occurred over a relatively brief period and the opposition has not had an enormous amount of time to look at the correspondence that has been referred by Senator Hill. And I suspect that the minister has not had a great amount of time to look more closely perhaps at the issues that have been raised by Dr Lawrence, although we are pleased with some of the assurances that Senator Hill has been able to give on those matters, which I will not repeat but which Senator Hill has read into the Hansard.

I say to the minister: if he wishes to take more time to consider the issue of a formal referral to the AHC and he thinks that would be useful, the opposition certainly would give it very favourable consideration. We would support a motion to adjourn the debate to a later hour of the day or a future sitting day if that was a useful contribution. Perhaps a fuller response might be forthcoming from the minister. From the perspective of the opposition, the issue of a formal reference to the AHC for proper assessment and consideration of prudent and feasible alternatives is, I think, the key one now that is outstanding. I think it is a matter of regret that Senator Hill has brought this matter to the stage of putting the regulations before parliament before seeking advice from the AHC and the EPA. I think Senator Hill well understands that it is within his own discretion to refer these matters whenever he wishes.

In the absence of referrals and advice from the two agencies, I think the opposition certainly finds itself in an invidious position—I do not know what the position of other non-government senators in the chamber is. I would ask Senator Hill to assure the Senate that, if the AHC or the EPA advise him that this experiment is environmentally unsound or inadvisable, he will accept that advice and not proceed. I hope he is willing to give that level of assurance to the Senate on this particular matter.

I note in the minister's contribution his concerns about the difficult position that he might be placed in if he does not take the scientific advice that is available to him and if there is a serious deterioration in fish stocks on the reef. He indicated that a precautionary approach was appropriate. I thought the same precautionary approach was sadly lacking in the Port Hinchinbrook development on the Great Barrier Reef, and I am pleased to see that the precautionary principle is uppermost in the minister's mind.

I say again that the issue of a formal AHC referral is the outstanding matter. I ask the minister to give serious consideration to that and also give serious consideration to assuring the Senate that, if there is advice from the AHC or the EPA that the experiment itself is environmentally unsound or should not be proceeded with, he would in that circumstance accept that advice and not proceed with the experiment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been impressed by the arguments of Senator Hill and Senator Faulkner on the substantive issue. I am somewhat disappointed that Senator Faulkner, having agreed with the necessity for the experiment, has decided on procedural grounds to support the Democrats' motion at this stage, although I do understand that Senator Faulkner is saying that if there were certain further discussions about this during the day he may be able to come to a different conclusion.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I am not familiar with the procedures, so I really cannot comment on the matter that Senator Faulkner raised lastly. It does, however, seem that any further technical procedures that need to be done may well—as I say, I am no expert on this—delay the experiment to such an extent that it becomes not as appropriate. I would hope that Senator Faulkner and the Labor Party will support the first part of Senator Faulkner's argument—that is, the argument in which he clearly acknowledged the need, the necessity and the importance of the experiment—and will support us and vote against the Democrats' disallowance motion and not allow the procedures that others want to adopt to interfere with what is a most important experiment.

I thought Senator Faulkner and Senator Hill put the arguments against the disallowance very clearly—perhaps better than I could. I wanted to enter the debate for three additional reasons. There are a couple of things that I want to add to the substantive part of the debate. I also speak in the debate because the experiment is being operated out of Townsville. Of course, having my electorate office there and living in the area, I come in contact with the scientists who are doing the experiment and with the people who use the reef and use the fish stock of the reef. They have approached me and said, `Can you please tell the Democrats just how stupid they are on this particular issue and tell them to get out of the way of an important experiment.'

The fishing interests, both the commercial and the recreational fishermen, initially were a bit concerned about the project because, as Senator Hill and Senator Faulkner have said, there are 16 reefs being dealt with. Eight of them are reefs that are currently open for fishing. Those eight will be closed for five years, but the ones that are being opened will be open for only one year. So the fishing interests were initially concerned about it because they thought they were getting the wrong end of the deal. But they eventually realised that the whole purpose of this experiment is to make sure that the fish stock is managed properly and that their industry is viable for many years in the future. That is why they are very keen to see this, even though, in the short term, it will be at a net cost to their availability of fishing.

One of the reasons why I am speaking is that they have asked me to enter into the debate to say to the Democrats and the Greens that we support this experiment. The Cooperative Research Centre—the Reef Research Centre based at James Cook University, with Professor Chris Crossland, who is very well regarded—has also approached me to do what I can to ensure that this very necessary experiment goes forward. Professor Crossland is one of the recognised experts in this field. The CRC at James Cook University in Townsville is very well recognised and very well regarded. These people would not be doing this experiment if there was any problem at all. Speaking as a sort of representative of the scientific community and the fishing community in North Queensland, I enter into this debate to urge, particularly, the Labor Party not to support this motion for disallowance.

The other reason that I enter into this debate is to vent my annoyance at the noisy minorities who are trying to run this country. The Democrats and Greens concede that they have no scientific expertise, but they seem to say they know better than these very well qualified, very well regarded scientists. So, again, we have the noisy minority, the Democrats and the Greens, the people who, in the Lindsay by‐election, were shown to have three per cent support, now trying to interfere in things that the Labor Party acknowledges should be done, even though they are unhappy about the procedures; the government parties acknowledge these things should be done, as do the scientific community and the fishing community—everybody except the Democrats and the Greens. I am again expressing my annoyance that Australia is going to be held to ransom by this noisy minority without any significant scientific support to stop this very worthwhile experiment.

I want to reiterate what the experiment actually is so that people understand what it is all about. The experiment hinges on the exact measure of fishing pressures on 16 reefs—that is 16 out of about 3,000 reefs on the Great Barrier Reef—over a period of just 12 months. Eight of the reefs are currently closed to fishing and will be closed again after the 12 months of measured fishing. So for 12 months they will be opened and then they will be closed again.

The other eight reefs have always been open to fishing, but after the 12 months of measured fishing they will be closed for five years. That is the problem the fishing industry initially had, before they worked out that this was very beneficial for the long‐term fish stock. So, after 12 months of measured fishing in those reefs that have been open, they will be closed for a whole five years. Effectively, through the life of the experiment, more reefs will be closed than are at present. At the end of the experiment all the reefs will revert to their current status.

The fish stock size is what is being looked at. Catch rates are often used as an index of the stock size. The assumption has been unavoidable in many fisheries but has generally been found to be wrong and has contributed substantially to fisheries collapses. One of the questions that the experiment will be looking at is how quickly fish populations recover following closure. Closure of reefs after fishing of known amounts will allow the experimenters to answer questions such as: how long does a reef have to be closed to fishing before populations have recovered and how do you measure the recovery? Does an increase in catch rates mean the abundance and biomass of fish has increased or just that the fish on a closed reef are easier to catch because they have not been fished for a while? These questions are central to evaluating any system of periodic or area closures as management strategies for the GBR reef line fishery.

It is important to emphasise that this experiment will never have to be repeated. Researchers will be able to model on computers with the data collected at this time to give accurate predictions of the level of fishing which the reefs can sustain. So it is a once‐only thing and involves a small amount of reefs. As Senator Hill has guaranteed at the request of the opposition, this is all going to be reviewed in a year. That was part of the CRC proposal. After one year the experiment will be reviewed and if it is not delivering the expected results it will be stopped.

The public may well ask: why do we need to manipulate fishing pressure? The effects of the fishing experiment is the only way to find out how reef fish populations respond to increased fishing pressure. The traditional approach to fisheries management is to monitor the past behaviour of the fishery and, based on that history and biological information about target species, attempt to predict sustainable catches for the future. This is more guesswork than science. That is what the scientists say—it is just an informed guess; it is not a science. They want to move it into a scientific category. By the time the nation realises we are in trouble with these fisheries in the way we have done it in the past, there is too much fishing effort, too many boats, and costly action then has to be taken to reduce it to sustainable levels.

I want briefly to refute some of the arguments that the Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland in the Proserpine‐Whitsunday area have been raising, which seem to be the basis on which the Democrats have moved this motion. I point out that the experiment will not, as alleged by the Democrats, result in fishing out of any reefs. Pilot studies have indicated there will still be viable populations of target species after controlled fishing.

I also want to emphasise that, contrary to the allegations of the Democrats, there will be no sponsored fishing nor will there be any spearfishing of every fish seen, as apparently has been alleged will happen on the control reefs. It is important also to emphasise that, contrary to allegations, the data collected from the total catch, including secondary species, will be analysed as part of the experiment. It is particularly important—and this is an objective of the project—to know the secondary effects on non-target species, particularly on the green reefs.

PARA.BREAK: Further, there is no evidence that the reefs in the general use area of the Great Barrier Reef are already severely overfished—as alleged. The fish stocks seem to be in reasonable shape, but the managers have no evi dence of their robustness or fragility. Fisheries collapse without warning, and that is why scientific experiments need to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, contrary to allegations from opponents of this experiment, it is not possible to computer model the effects of fishing on stocks when the critical data are missing. You can do it once you have the critical data, but you have to get that critical data. Models were purpose built to test and verify the design of the experiment, but those models will not be adequate to evaluate management options because they need information which is currently not available and which the experiment is designed to get.

Contrary also to some of the more outrageous claims of the opponents of this experiment, the experiment is not—I repeat, not—being funded by the fishing industry. That allegation seems to have been thrown in to try to garner a bit of support. Further, the study of the reproductive biology of fish populations, particularly the coral trout, is an integral part of the whole study of the fishery. A lot of allegations have been made by the Democrats and other opponents. None of them stand up to scientific scrutiny, and they have been rejected by the people who should know.

I want to conclude by raising a couple of comments that various people involved in this matter have said. Senator Hill has already mentioned Dr Alan Butler, the president of the Marine Science Association of Australia. Dr Butler has given total support to the experiment and has published his support quite widely on behalf of the Marine Science Association of Australia.

I asked in an interjection across the chamber before why on earth these marine scientists, whose whole purpose in life is to protect the Great Barrier Reef and the fishing stock, are supporting this experiment if it is not important. Senator Margetts replied to my interjection by saying, `They have their own agenda.' I think she said they were in it for the short‐term money or something like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. You are quoting me out of context.
—Sorry?
—You wait until you hear what I have to say, instead of quoting me out of context.

—Unfortunately, I will not be able to answer that because I am speaking now. Why on earth would these experts want to damage the reef if this experiment is going to be as bad as Senator Lees has said? Certainly Dr Alan Butler does not think it will be, and the scientists at James Cook University do not think so, either.

BREAK.PARA: I remember there was a time when the Democrats and the Greens were relying on some scientists—I must say they were pretty low order scientists—at James Cook University to support their opposition to the Oyster Point issue. Now they are apparently just going to ignore those world leaders in the scientific area who are saying, `Go ahead and support this,' because it seems they know better than the scientists.
I will just give some examples of the comments in the newspapers. The Canberra Times said:
. . . the scientists, from James Cook University, say the experiment is crucial to the protection of the reef and that the Democrats claims are emotive.
It continued:
Project leader, Dr Bruce Mapstone, said the experiment was crucial if fisheries were to be managed sustainably in the future. His group had not received any funding from the fishing industry . . .
That is another quote confirming something I have said before. The Courier‐Mail reported:
The Queensland Fisheries Management Authority also attacked Democrats Senator Meg Lees for her stance on the James Cook University line‐fishing experiment.
QFMA reef fisheries resource manager . . . said time was running out for efforts to manage the Reef fishery.
Another paper stated that a recreational anglers' organisation, Sunfish North Queensland, had also attacked those opponents for their:
. . . aggressive, ill-informed stance in misleading the public with general mistruths over a proposed Great Barrier Reef research program.

I emphasise again that in the short term these recreational and commercial fisheries will be the losers because the reefs that they currently fish will be closed for five years. The new reefs that are being opened will be open for only one year.

For all of these reasons, we really must get on with the experiment and reject this motion. I understand that some of the matters Senator Faulkner raised are being further considered, and he suggested to me that it would be better if this debate proceeded at a later time. I appreciate that others do wish to speak on this, but it perhaps would be a more informed debate if we concluded it at some other time. For that reason, I seek leave to continue my remarks on 18 November 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The fallacy that occurs because of the rich colour and the variety in reefs is that we have a rich and robust environment. That is wrong from a biological point of view: reefs are the equivalent of an undersea desert. The fact that there are so many varieties in this undersea desert is the outcome of being a very fragile area which responds very quickly to changes in nutrient levels and to a number of different environmental changes. One of the reasons why reefs and corals are being looked at around the world is to see the likely impact of things like bleaching occurrences and so on on further changes in the greenhouse levels around the world, changes in the temperatures of currents and changes in pollution levels. The reefs, if you like, become the canary of pollution and change in the world. That is very important to see.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, reefs are very fragile ecosystems. Unfortunately, the government's contribution that we have heard today is fairly limited in thinking of reefs as only a source of fish. It is a bit like thinking of old-growth or ancient forests as a source of timber or, worse still, thinking of old-growth or ancient forests simply as a source of woodchips. It is not that. The reefs are fragile ecosystems, and they need to be considered as such when we are talking about the government's responsibilities in relation to the reefs.

BREAK.PARA: Honourable senators may remember that I recently placed a notice of motion to the Senate in relation to the reef line fishing experiment. It stated `That the Senate notes, with concern, the recent decision' and so on. Then part (b) reads:
. . . calls on the Minister to table:
(i) the research outline for the reefline fishing experiment in protected zones, as proposed by the Cooperative Research Centre; and
(ii) details of the level of scientific peer review of the research outline and the manner in which this review has been organised.

I have received some of that information back from the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), but my request was that that information be tabled. I am quite happy to table my copy. If by the end of this debate it is not tabled, then I am happy to table the copy that I have. I guess that would need to be copied so that other people can see it. We have asked for the information to be tabled. It is really quite important that this information is tabled. The information is nowhere near complete. However, the third page of the research outline entitled Effects of line fishing: experiment, design and timing states:
The Reef Line fishery is currently undergoing substantial changes, especially in the commercial sectors.
We have this little note here. There should be bells ringing that there are commercial pressures pushing this experiment. What are those pressures? Here we go:
In particular, changes in marketing (the growth of the live fish trade) . . .

What we know is that the live fish trade is driving this experiment. What is this live fish trade? There are two elements to the live fish trade, and we need more information about which element is pushing this experiment. One is live fish for eating and the other is live fish for aquariums.

We are seeing a great deal of evidence that the trade in live fish for aquariums throughout the world is responsible for what is largely killing reefs throughout the world. We are hearing evidence of cyanide and so on being used in pushing for that trade. Is this a trade that the Australian government should be encouraging? Should they be doing that to the detriment of the ecological communities?

The reefs are not just a source of fish; they are a very complex ecological community, the parts of which are so intertwined that, when you remove one portion, other parts suffer. You may not only be getting rid of adult fish; you may be interfering with this complex ecological community, which may lead to the killing or changing—maybe forever—of aspects of the reef.

Why would you do this? It is really quite interesting because all around the Indo-Pacific region we have reefs which have similar ecological communities. If you wanted to find out what the impacts are of either overfishing pristine reefs or overfishing reefs to the point of extinction, you have many examples within the region. Experiments have been carried out again and again throughout the region.

It also has to be understood that the nature of the experiment conducted on the reef is very important. You cannot just put a cage around the reef and say, `This is a controlled experiment within the reef.' The reason you cannot do that is that what happens on one reef affects what happens on other reefs. It is not just within the Great Barrier Reef that changes within pristine reefs will have an impact—there is no indication that the rest of the reef will be monitored at the same time for the impact, only those areas within the study area—but also the reefs around the Indo-Pacific area for which things like coral spawn are carried from the currents.

This is not fanciful. Coral spawning in one part of the world then becomes the basis for continued healthy coral reefs in other parts of the world. This is not part of the experiment either. There is no indication that we will have monitoring set up in those other reefs throughout the world which benefit from the healthy nature of some of our coral reefs in the Great Barrier Reef. What controlled research will there be in the reefs elsewhere in the Indian-Pacific region? Nothing to indicate that that will be the case.

The experiment has been changed from four years to two years. Is this change in timing `scientific'? No. It also mentioned in this outline that change from four years to two years is necessitated by the need to formally amend the zoning plans which in fact are driving this proposal.

Senator Ian Macdonald talks about the levels of fishing that the reef can sustain. That is what we are beginning to see. If we are saying that we need to make this experiment two years in length, we are talking about the desire not just to project the reef but to change the zoning so that, in the future, we can continue to have reefs which are not protected from fishing but about which we have some crass idea of assimilative capacity. If you want to know of scientists who have criticised the whole concept of assimilative capacity, I can get plenty of scientists to provide that kind of critique. It is a very odd idea about the precautionary principle that we are hearing today.

What is a national park? What signal are we giving to other countries in the region? It is my understanding that Australian scientists are working very hard in other parts of the region, including the Philippines and other places, to convince local communities that closing off reefs to fishing will be of benefit in many ways. It is happening successfully. What kind of signal will it give to those communities if Australia is doing what appears to be exactly the opposite?

We cannot wait to see what happens when we close off the reef. We are in too much of a hurry, so we will do the exact opposite. We will either fish out or more intensively fish blue reefs. That is what is happening. The blue reefs will be more intensively fished, or perhaps come close to being fished out, and we will open our otherwise pristine reefs. That is exactly the opposite of what we and Australian scientists overseas are asking the fishing communities in other countries to do. We are asking them to take some care for the overall long-term benefits, yet we are doing the exact opposite.

PARA.BREAK: The research outline and methodology review process need very careful consideration. There has been all this talk about scientific analysis and processes. In the normal case of these kind of scientific experiments, you measure `effort'. If you were going to do this as a proper scientific experi ment, you would require, I would think, a log of what size and type of fish the fishing companies are catching. But are they requiring that? No. You have to wonder exactly how scientific this experiment is if you are only talking about the numbers of fish but not requiring even a log from those people who will suddenly be allowed to fish in otherwise pristine and protected areas. Comparative studies of live and dead fish are not valid in a scientific sense. We could find a number of scientists who could give reasons why this kind of comparison is not valid.

BREAK.PARA: What does this all say about the future? It is not making very good statements about the current processes and attitude of the government. We have already seen the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) come into this chamber and say that the way to deal with the problem of bluefin tuna, which is very controversial, is to give increased access to it by fishing fleets. He believes that that would solve the problem. That is not giving us a very good signal of how this government sees the issue of depleted fish stocks and the whole marine ecosystem.

Unfortunately, in the case of fishing, it is very difficult to isolate one area of the sea and say, `We can deal with this issue because it is in everybody's interest to take the same line.' In the north-west cape in Western Australia, you have a reasonably closed ecosystem. You can monitor those areas. If you have people with limited licences, there is a coming together of interests between fishing and other interests, such as pollution and so on. That happens when there is a limited number of licences and where under‐fishing or controlled fishing becomes the rationale for real sustainability.

In the case where it is impossible to put a line around what is or is not part of a particular fishing area, this whole process becomes an understanding that fish stocks are threatened, that reefs may be threatened and that commercial pressures may bring extra pressures in the future. Each of those players might be looking to see how they can benefit in the short term if they know that there is no way of controlling the long term. That is the worst spin of it, but it has been asked why people would do such a thing. Perhaps the answer is to see how far we can get away with the level of exploitation that we would want to get away with. That is not the way to treat a national park. It is not the way to deal with such a precious and valuable ecological community.

It is quite difficult, just as it is in Western Australia, for people to speak up and give alternative critiques. In Western Australia, it involves scientists from the Department of Conservation and Land Management. There are great parallels here. In Western Australia, the scientists from the Department of Conservation and Land Management have a number of conflicting interests. They include forestry and the demand to continue receiving royalties.

There are also these conflicting interests within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. That is not something that is bad about the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, but it is the reality. You have tourism, fishing and recreational interests and you obviously have conservation interests. The reality is that there are conflicts of interest. There are people who would like to see whether they can do things in a different way instead of operating by the principle of actual conservation. They would like to see just how far they can damage an area and still get away with it. That is not a good principle or the message Australia should be sending to those countries where we are desperately trying to get communities to look at their long-term interests.

There are species of fish within a reef that go to the reef only in their juvenile stage and which move off the reef later. There is probably a reasonable argument to say that the total level of fish will increase if you do lock out areas of reef. If we are talking about coral trout and so on, maybe those fish can be gained in other ways, such as through carefully designed aquaculture.

There are many issues. I do not think there is any indication at all that the government has gone through proper processes in making the decisions here. I think that it is proper that this motion be supported today because it was an improper decision, in my view, to go ahead so quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. This is the first time that you have been in the chair when I have risen to my feet. I wish you well in your job as Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, I wish to canvass an aspect of the euthanasia debate which I find profoundly interesting, given my outspokenness on that aspect, which has engendered considerable public comment. In my first speech in this place, I stressed the importance of having a truly federal system of government. Those who served with me on the legal and constitutional affairs committee of the Senate and the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties would be aware of my continual concern at treaties impinging on the legislative domain of the states.

In November 1994 I voted for the rights of the legislature of my home state of Tasmania against the views adopted by my party. In short, I believe that I have some credentials to speak on the issue of the impact of the bill introduced by the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, on what has been dubbed territory rights. Today, I do not wish to canvass the merits of the Northern Territory's euthanasia legislation. However, views have been expressed in the community on the issue of territory rights. It seems to be used in the same context as states rights.

This appeal to territory rights in the context of the euthanasia debate is baseless and intellectually unsustainable. The rights of territories are simply that bundle of rights bestowed upon a territory by the goodwill of this the Commonwealth parliament. The foundation of the Northern Territory's alleged rights are rooted in the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1978, passed by the Commonwealth parliament. Therefore, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly only exists by virtue of the federal parliament's goodwill. What the parliament gives, it can also take away.

This is in stark contrast to the states, which combined to form the Commonwealth and federal parliament for specific purposes. The states pre‐dated the Commonwealth. A quick read of our constitution provides the salient differences and exposes the shallowness of talking territory rights in the same breath as states rights.

Section 122 of our constitution was drafted by our founding fathers and democratically accepted by the peoples of the various states. It has been part of the legislative province of the federal parliament since the inception of the constitution and has remained so ever since. Section 122 reads in part, as follows:
The parliament may make laws for the government of any territory . . .
Nothing could be clearer. No highly paid QCs are needed for this one. It is crystal clear—literally black on white:
The parliament may make laws for the government of any territory . . .

It is under that power that the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act was enacted. This act provides for the appointment of an administrator of the Northern Territory by the Governor-General. The same legislation under section 9 allows for disallowance of any Legislative Assembly enactment, once again, by the Governor-General. `Governor-General' in this context means the federal executive, or a simple cabinet decision.

BREAK.PARA: Under section 53 of the Northern Territory (Self‐ Government) Act, the federal Industrial Relations Act applies in relation to industrial disputes in the territory. Each state has its own industrial relations regime—not so the territories. Under section 23 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self‐Government) Act, there are matters specifically excluded from the ACT Legislative Assembly's power to make laws, ranging over numerous matters and issues, including the classification of materials for the purposes of censorship—a power enjoyed and exercised by each and every state. Given the behaviour of the ACT on this issue, it is little wonder that the federal parliament refused to trust the ACT with the power to classify and censor.

In relation to the Australian Capital Territory (Self‐ Government) Act of 1988, I note that the Governor-General has the power to dissolve the ACT Legislative Assembly under section 16 and appoint a commissioner, similar to the power that the state governments enjoy in relation to local councils. But do we hear the state premiers condemning the interference by state governments in local government affairs? Hardly likely, given their quite high‐handed treatment, on occasions, of local government.

The premiers' response would undoubtedly be that local government is set up by state legislation and that the state governments therefore have a right to determine how local governments operate, and their electors in their various states will ultimately judge them in due course. I agree with them. But if that is—and we know it is—the response of state premiers, then they cannot complain about the Commonwealth parliament dealing in exactly the same way with creations of its own legislation, namely the territories.
I trust the point has been made: territories are hardly in the same category as the states, which the Constitution Act reminds us created the Commonwealth when its preamble tells us:

Whereas the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania, humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God, have agreed to unite in one indissoluble Federal Commonwealth . . .

In short, to talk about states' rights in the context of a territory is to demean the currency of federalism. It is galling in the extreme to witness the Paul‐like conversion of commentators to the principle of states' rights when they have previously dismissed them. They supported federal intervention to take away land management decisions from a state—denying a clean hydro‐power scheme in favour of fossil fuels under the ludicrous guise of an international responsibility to the environment—or the interference in a state's right to determine its own criminal code.

Yet on a subject dealing with the issue of life and death of Australian citizens, we are suddenly confronted by a frenzied breast-beating and chanting of not states rights but territory rights. Those who oppose the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill on states rights grounds look with absolute amazement at the disingenuous arguments and intellectual dishonesty of those now promoting the new found concept of territory rights whilst they retain a strange silence on states rights.

The case for the states retaining their legislative provinces is a lot stronger, indeed overwhelming, given the founding fathers' drafting of the constitution and its acceptance by our forebears through referenda. The real effort ought be put into restoring the federal balance which has been so badly undermined by international treaty making, so-called international jurisprudence and our own High Court's desire to play politician legislator rather than judge.

A lot of woolly thinking has given expression to this claim of territory rights. In applying this concept in the context of states rights there has been a demeaning of federalism and a misunderstanding of our constitutional history and the role of the territories. Requests to uphold the integrity of the constitution and the federal balance are welcome but simultaneously severely undermined when those same requests embrace the territories for which the Commonwealth parliament has a clear and unambiguous legislative responsibility.

Like state governments that can sack local councils, amalgamate them and foist their own planning legislation on them, this federal parliament must similarly determine whether or not to deal with a creation of its legislation—the territories—in a like fashion. That is an appropriate consideration and a matter which ought exercise our collective mind as a federal parliament. But in exercising our mind on this matter, we should not obfuscate the debate and our considerations by hiding behind an intellectually unsustainable argument by appealing to territory rights which have no basis in constitutional law.

Given that this parliament has the clear and unambiguous right to legislate in relation to the territories, the only question remaining is whether it should exercise that clear and unambiguous right. I would assert to this parliament that it should only do so on the rarest of occasions.

But, when no other equivalent country or state has legislated in a similar manner and when the legislation deals with the most fundamental issue facing its citizenry, that of life and death, I believe we have the firm foundation required for justifying the exercise of the Commonwealth's clear and unambiguous power—a power granted not by dubious international treaties or contorted High Court decisions but from the power specifically crafted and provided to us as a parliament by our founding fathers and accepted by our forebears in referenda.

Federalism and the role of the states in our Australian body politic are commodities too precious to be diluted by ill‐considered notions of territory rights. In short, territories ain't states. Let the debate continue on whether this parliament ought exercise its clear and unambiguous powers on the merits of the euthanasia issue.

One thing is certain in my mind, and that is that the credibility of credit unions and building societies is diminished by the Queensland situation. No doubt there are parties in the banking sector that may benefit from all this, but we are all the losers when confidence, diversity and competition diminish. What is the big secret that the financial systems inquiry is perhaps trying to hide? My constituents have put it thus to the inquiry:

Building Societies and Credit Unions should not be responsible for the management of superannuation funds in any form on the basis that the regulator of those institutions (QOFS) is not capable of acting on complaints from members and shareholders of these financial institutions.
Matters that we—
my constituents—

have raised go to the very essence of the rule of law in Australia; a person has been victimised by a financial institution following his giving of evidence to a Queensland Commission of inquiry and when confronted with this evidence, the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision did not act. Senator Harradine has repeatedly made comments addressing the issues of abortion and family matters, and they are high principles also.
