We would be most surprised if Senator Harradine departed from the principles that he has articulated in this chamber over a period of 20 years. I have been surprised that the five female senators in the Australian Democrats have deliberately chosen to depart from the principles that they have articulated publicly, privately and on the public record in this place.

I make particular reference to the role of female workers in the workplace, by and large unskilled, by and large without high levels of education and often without the opportunity to progress through a career path. They seek simple things: a fair go, security in employment, guarantees of continuing employment, guarantees in the allocations of hours and regularity in rosters. These are not unremarkable demands and every other person in this place would accept them as the norm. Female workers, particularly those at the bottom end of the chain, need those things because they have a dual commitment. They have a work commitment that raises finances to fund their families and they have an obvious family commitment to their partners and to their children.

Many people suggest that that is in a process of change and that things will become much more equal over time. My view is that, much as the institutions and structures of society change, the role of females in the family will continue to be a caring and nurturing role. It might change and go into other areas, but that will still be a task that falls to them. Accordingly, if they are to enter the workplace, if they are to carry out tasks in the workplace, they need strong support in the family to carry out their caring and nurturing activities.

One of the things that female workers in the retail, hospitality, cleaning and service industries need is the knowledge of regularity of hours and the guarantee of continuing hours. It has been clearly demonstrated in a range of reports, and by every day observations, that these workers do not have a high level of skills, that by and large they are poorly educated and that they are confined to sectors of work that do not have a high wage. The flexibility that is sought by employers, and articulated by a range of interests in this place, is sometimes not the flexibility that they need. They need guarantees and securities.

The litany of complaints that I had from female workers over my 15 years as a union official in the retail industry can be reduced to two or three basics. They were not significantly complaints about the award or about the levels of salary—although, more was always desirable, but it was not a pressing issue—but that, as casuals or non full‐time workers, there was no guarantee of hours and no maximum number of hours in their employment contract. They had no ability to plan into the future or the ability to determine their own future in both their family life and their work life.

BREAK.PARA: Female workers repeatedly said to me that they were unable to arrange finance from banking and finance institutions because they did not have set hours, a maximum number of hours, that they could guarantee as income to repay their loans. Because of that, as casual workers, they were unable to access building societies and banks, unable to purchase homes or to fund repayments of mortgage loans. They were denied a place in our community because they had no maximum hours and hence could not persuade a bank manager or a bank clerk that they were deserving of a loan.

In the retail industry, the norm in all state awards and agreements, and federal awards and agreements was a minimum of 10 hours per week and a maximum of 30 hours to 34 hours per week, often converted to a fortnightly roster or a monthly roster to give flexibility. In all my time as a union official, representing tens of thousands of people, I never had a complaint that a maximum of 32 or 34 hours per week, or a minimum of nine, 10 or 12 hours per week was inadequate or oppressive or did not give access to sufficient income or could not be changed.

The marketplace in that industry determined a result, by negotiation, of a minimum of nine to 12 hours and a maximum of 28 to 34 hours per week. This result was achieved over many years, not through arbitration and not through strikes, but by negotiation. It was a result that was acceptable to the work force, by and large a female work force, and it was a result that was acceptable to the major and minor employers in the industry. The only company that I ever recall seeking more than 32 hours a week was David Jones and that was for reasons particular to that company.

It seems to me that, in the context of looking after female workers, low‐paid workers and those who do not have great ability to advance their own interest, one would consult with those persons before seeking changes. Indeed, the theme of consultation, of talking, of setting up structures to facilitate those objectives is a recurring feature in many of the speeches given by the female senators of the Australian Democrats.

Unfortunately, it is a fine sentiment that is often difficult to convert to practice and, in a range of issues under discussion lately, it has been deliberately ignored. In fact, the word `betrayal' comes strongly to mind when describing the actions of those female senators in betraying their own gender and those people whom they profess to look after and whose interests they profess to advance.

It is a betrayal of their own principles; a betrayal of feminist principles. It is also a betrayal of the basic fundamentals that they say they stand for and would seek to advance in this place. But, when it comes to the test, when the power is there, they choose to avoid it and to use it for other purposes. The betrayal of those principles, in respect of female workers, by those female senators would be akin to Senator Harradine taking money to change his position on the abortion vote, and no‐one in this place would ever suggest that such a thing would occur.

But, apparently, when it applies to female workers, the female representatives of the Australian Democrats—Senator Allison, Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Kernot—do not think it is important. It was not important because two days of headlines in the national press were pleasing, and gratifying and showed flexibility. Sometimes those things are not sufficient and what is more important is attachment to principle and articulation of principle, particularly when it is those principles that have brought those persons into this place.

It is entirely proper in this matter of public interest to address that concept of principle, power and politics and to make pertinent references to the role of the various parties in this place, as they address issues of public concern in the public forum. They have repeatedly said that they seek to attach themselves to that mast. Indeed, Senator Allison concluded her first speech by saying:
I look forward to the day when women will cross the floor in solidarity and when the strength of argument regularly influences the vote. Madam President, I look forward to my term of office.
In the first instance, when Senator Allison could have chosen to exercise her principle, she failed. Senator Stott Despoja, in her first speech, said:

If I can speak at all for the youth of this country it is to say that we want to respect our institutions and our leaders and we want to pursue change that makes individuals free and able to pursue their hopes and dreams whatever their circumstances.
Fine sentiments. When referring to the Youth Poll she said:

It shows a very caring generation—caring about employment prospects and concerned about their families and teenage suicide levels . . . However, it is true that young people show disdain for politicians and are cynical about the political process. The Youth Poll shows that only 1.5 per cent of young people trust us.

That is not surprising, when Senator Stott Despoja is leading the charge to betray youth workers in the retail industry and in the hospitality industry and deny them guarantees to maximum hours of employment, and deny them finance, banking and the opportunity to purchase homes. They are denying single mothers the opportunity to participate fully in our society and married couples the opportunity to plan their futures. That is the legacy that the female senators in the Australian Democrats leave with us today.

It is interesting, though, that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister should take time out of what should be a very busy schedule. But, as Senator Evans said, native title is not going anywhere and there are a whole number of things Senator Minchin has responsibility for that are not going anywhere. So he responds to one particular individual whom I have never met but whose articles I certainly do enjoy reading from time to time.

I wonder if Senator Minchin is also going to reply to what I think was a brilliant article by Alan Ramsey that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday, 2 November. It was entitled `Replay of `88 to haunt Howard'. There was another article next to that one which related the events that occurred in 1988 and was entitled `Racist "missile" finds its mark eight years on'.

There is something very disturbing in our society, which unfortunately, according to articles and for those of us that lived through the debates at the time, seems to be being repeated now. For example, Mr Ramsey has this to say in his article:
Nothing has changed in the latest debate . . .
He is referring to 1996 as opposed to 1988. He continues:

A Hawke government‐sponsored inquiry into Australian attitudes found, in part: `Racism is by no means excised from Australia. There were outbreaks of yobbo racism: cars sprayed, houses daubed, a garage burnt down in Adelaide, and wide media reportage of `ugly incidents' in which Asians were `abused and spat at'.

It is unfortunate that some things do repeat themselves in later years. With the carriage of the resolution in the parliament of Australia last week, with bipartisan support, I hope that many of the events referred to here will not recur in Australia.

But it is interesting to reflect on the events leading into last Wednesday's debate. The resolution was an agreed resolution between the main political parties. It was only when the thoughts of the public were expressed through the media—and I have only referred here to a part of that outrage—that the Prime Minister, possibly at the influence of his parliamentary secretary, though one would doubt that very much, actually came to the party and agreed to meet a representative of the opposition and to agree on a form of words acceptable to all parties in the parliament.
I will quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of last Saturday, 2 November, which said:

The Liberal Party's doyenne, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, former head of its National Women's Advisory Council had both blame and praise for Mr Howard and the Federal Opposition Leader, Mr Beazley, for finally passing a bipartisan motion abhorring racism.
Dame Beryl is quoted as saying:
`At this stage I think what they have done is fine, but I only wish they had done it earlier.'
Mr Beazley tried, but Mr Beazley does not have the numbers in the other place in order to press the matter forward.

But we can claim a victory, and all fair‐minded people in Australia can claim a victory, by the passage of that motion last week. One reason I am very pleased it was passed last week in the House, and carried unanimously, is that when we refer back to the election campaign earlier this year, Ms Hanson is not the only member of parliament who was involved in making racist remarks before the election. Neither is Mr Campbell, a former member of my own party from Western Australia.

We may recall one candidate for the National Party of Australia, from the state of Queensland, who made some not very complimentary remarks about citizenship ceremonies. I think he referred to them as `de‐wogging ceremonies'. He was criticised by his leader at the time but retained his candidature for the ongoing election. What was very disappointing at the time was that a sitting member of parliament, another National Party member, Mr Bob Katter, actually went public and defended Mr Burgess for the remarks that he had made. In actual fact, Mr Katter took the matter somewhat further with his comments, which I do not care to repeat in this place.

I note with pleasure that it would appear that Mr Katter supported the motion for the joint statement in the House of Representatives last week. I hope that is the case, that he has reflected on some of the earlier remarks that have been attributed to him and that now he and all other members of parliament can fulfil their obligations to the parliament and to the people of Australia, doing everything in their power to end this very damaging debate that is going on.

When I say `damaging', I am not referring merely to the economic damage that may be done to our trade with our partners in the region. I think the debate that has been happening, especially some of the contributions from some of the people that have participated in it, is damaging the human spirit and the human being. Overall and over time, that will be the greatest damage—far greater than any economic damage that might result from this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address an issue with regard to a matter of public interest. It relates to a commitment that politicians and parties give to people when they go to elections, and the factors on which people vote for individuals and parties in elections.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance I wish to address the credibility and the commitment of the Liberal and National parties and also the Democrats. Prior to the 2 March election they espoused commitments to the electorate, to the people of Australia. It seems that, once elected, parties take the opportunity to do exactly the opposite of their commitments—in fact, to renege and/or rat on what they have committed themselves to through their policies and public statements with regard to various issues.

I find it rather curious in relation to the Liberal and National parties, the coalition that was elected to government. During the election campaign, the so‐called `race for the battlers', Mr Howard said that those were the two parties which stood best to represent the battlers of Australia and the workers of Australia. Indeed, he said on many occasions that no worker would be worse off under a Howard led administration. Clearly, however, that is not going to be the case.

What is worse is the position of the Australian Democrats, who have often claimed themselves to be the custodians of social equity, the party that `keeps the bastards honest', and who have proclaimed on many occasions that they represent those that major parties do not. I find it rather unusual that we now see an alliance between the Democrats and the coalition government on a particular issue that is of such fundamental importance to working and battling Australians.

As has been addressed by two other senators earlier in the debate on matters of public interest, the question of hours of work for workers is of fundamental importance, particularly for female workers. Quite often, probably in the majority of cases, the families of the battlers have both parents working. Also, it has been put on many occasions that it is of fundamental importance that people have some idea of either the maximum or minimum hours of work that may be required of them.

We have seen this arrangement put in place in the Senate. I must say that I have the utmost respect for the Democrats, in particular for Senator Kernot. I do have a view in so far as Senator Andrew Murray is concerned that, unfortunately, due to his lack of knowledge of industrial relations in this country and his lack of experience in so far as industrial relations is concerned in this country, he has been well and truly led up the garden path by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith. He has then, maybe inadvertently, led the Democrats into a trap that has been set by the government—one that I feel will at some point in time come back to bite them very severely.

I just hope that at some point in time, when it is proven that the position that they are currently adopting in supporting the government with regard to industrial relations policy and changes is wrong, when the time comes that they see the error of their ways, they will have the courage of their convictions and of the policy and philosophies that they have espoused, both in this place and to the public in general. I hope that they will have the commitment and the courage to get up and—if we are still in opposition at that time—to support us in moving changes to legislation that may ultimately be adopted in this parliament, to ensure that we restore the rightful conditions and protections for workers in this country and, indeed, look after the families of Australia in the way that they deserve to be looked after. That includes male and female workers.

It really is unacceptable, and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has on many occasions, in a number of speeches, said that the problem with the parliament, and indeed the problem with politicians and with the credibility of political life being so low, arises because there is a view amongst the public—and it is probably true—that politicians never, ever stand by their word. I think that has been demonstrated, and is being demonstrated in the legislation that is being debated in this chamber at the moment.

I appeal to the Democrats, especially to Senator Kernot, at some point in time to reconsider their position. I hope that, when it is proven that the position that they have taken is wrong, that they have made a fundamental error, they will not be frightened but will have a true commitment to the convictions that I hope, at least, that they hold and will assist the opposition in bringing about the changes to restore the rightful protection and conditions for workers in this country that ought to be in place.

I sincerely hope that that sort of approach will not be lost on the Democrats. If they are to play a role, then they ought to play the role that they indicated to the Australian public they would play.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't even got 30 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: Many women saw the idea of a 35 per cent quota by 2002 as condescending.
Terry Sheahan made similar comments. He said:

One of the main obstacles for women gaining preselection, especially in safe seats is the old boy tradition, a man being lined up years ahead to take a seat when the incumbent retires. These sinecure positions invariably go to men.
That is not me saying those things, Madam President; that is a Labor Party stalwart saying those things.
Of course, the Women into Politics newsletter said:

The ALP, as it rebuilds, will not win women again unless they restrain the favouritism, cronyism, nepotism, the sometimes quite unconscious sexism and the factionalism so evident in the party and adopt the equal appointment opportunity rule . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister whether she can tell the House the further opportunities that the government has provided for women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The noise opposite makes it difficult to get this message across. I think the people of Australia want to know what we are doing to increase the number of women in politics. For example, we have already got Jackie Kelly back. That is a really big plus, thanks to the people of Lindsay. We have continued to support all our new members, of whom so many are women.

ANSWER.PARA: We are improving the consultation processes with women's organisations, Madam President. We are continuing to encourage women to be involved in the Liberal Party and to aim for places in the three levels of government. As to how our policies will assist women generally, let me remind you that our emphasis has been on economic independence for women, whether it is through a focus on jobs; whether it is through a focus on retirement income; whether it is through a focus on the alleviation of poverty caused by family break‐up—and you know that we have put preventative measures in there through marriage education, et cetera; whether through the alleviation of poverty caused by high housing costs. There are too many things, Madam President; I could go on for hours. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Bob Collins.
—Here is one of the old boys.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks old girl. My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, you are allowed to say `old boys', but you are not allowed to say `old girls', are you? Come on, you mob.
—Come on; just ask the question.

—Madam President, my question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Minister, are you aware of the previous government's produc tion and distribution of a document entitled Rebutting the myths: some facts about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs , which in fact addresses the nine most common misconceptions in the community about Aboriginal affairs? Given the joint resolution of this parliament last week, which I am pleased to say appeared to have some positive impact on public opinion, would you give consideration to updating and reissuing this document in the public interest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Collins, yes, I am aware. I have read that document, and I think that is an excellent idea. I will certainly do that because I think there is an enormous amount of ignorance in the population, some of it of course perpetuated and pushed by elements of the media, and in particular I refer to the attack today on salaries of ATSIC executives. The salaries are in line with standards across the service in terms of responsibilities, and are no different from any other band in the Public Service.

ANSWER.PARA: As you said yourself, Senator Bob Collins, it was a poor attempt at journalism. Particularly the headlines that were given were not commensurate with the articles that appeared. I particularly found reprehensible the attack on Patricia Turner who is one of the most outstanding public servants in this—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Lois.

—It was an attack on public servants, Senator Bolkus, more particularly, and an apparent linkage that in some way there was nepotism involved in her appointment. Since having this portfolio, I have been particularly impressed with her professionalism and her management of ATSIC, and grateful for the advice that I have received from her. She has worked unstintingly in the best traditions of the Public Service in the time that I have been responsible for this portfolio.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that those salary increases were as a result of Australian Public Service‐wide wage increases which applied to all Commonwealth public servants. I have been advised that there has been no increase in the number of senior executives employed by ATSIC. The increase in salary costs is as a result of APS‐wide wage increases for all staff, including senior executives, resulting in an increase in the number of senior executives whose salary packages now fall within the $110,000 to $120,000 range and thereby within the reporting arrangements for the first time. Similar wage movements have resulted in movements within the bands in the reporting arrangements. For example, there is now one person in the $170,000 to $179,999 range, and one person in the $180,000 to $189,999 range where previously, prior to salary increases, there was none.

So the headlines, as you correctly mentioned, were totally inconsistent with the article itself. As you quite rightly pointed out, this is the sort of myth that gets perpetuated. I am certainly using every opportunity to refute that myth. I accept your suggestion that such myths should be refuted in the wider community. I am referring to many of the urban myths that seem to exist, such as the one that the Aboriginal people are not the most disadvantaged in our society. That myth should be laid to rest once and for all. Unquestionably, on any criterion, whether it be housing, health, education, employment or, particularly, life expectancy, the Aboriginal people are the most disadvantaged in our society. The longer and the more frequently that all of us within the Senate itself speak out in the wider community, the more we will get that message through so that the various myths that seem to be perpetuated can be overcome by bringing out the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Yesterday I asked the minister what I thought was an important question on the progress of government plans to shift expenditure in areas like housing, health and aged care to the states. The most charitable description I could give to his response was that he waffled on long enough to make it seem as though enough time had passed and he could comfortably sit down. So I am asking you again, minister: given that this cost shifting strategy amounts to almost 30 per cent of budget outlays and is a significant part of your deficit reduction strategy and, given that the states are clearly unhappy about taking the power the way it is being handed over, does not the potential unravelling of your plan at next Monday's COAG represent a `silver bullet' to your budget strategy? If these arrangements do not work, what is plan B? What will you do if 30 per cent of your budget outlays are not available to you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to have again the chance to respond to the issues that Senator Kernot has raised. Senator Kernot, the major threat to the budget, I would have thought, came from people who were not prepared to accept that the budget measures which were announced mid‐August by the Treasurer, were extremely well received. Day after day we are treated to comments in the press—
—Go and tell industry that! They don't believe you.

—Go and tell the public that, Senator Cook! Remember Lindsay? The budget is now coming before this chamber. We are seeking to ensure that the budget, which has widespread public endorsement, is passed in full by this chamber. So I am surprised with you, Senator Kernot, standing up and arguing that you have particular concerns about the budget strategy, because we all now have a chance to vote on the budget strategy. We have put our budget down and we are looking forward to receiving your support. But that is not clear in every measure, if I can judge by the press reports.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the discussion with the states, you will be aware that there were meetings with the states in which the states recognised that something had to be done to address the major budget deficit—the black hole that was left by Mr Beazley and the Keating ministers that this government had to deal with. The states, from my memory, approached that through a constructive arrangement and agreements were reached.

As you point out, Senator Kernot, there will be discussions with the states on a range of issues. I am confident that they will be conducted in a very constructive and successful manner. We will not pre‐judge those discussions but we are confident that the states will come to the table in a very constructive manner.

The problems with the budget rest not so much with the states. The public is now focused on ensuring that the budget is given a fair go by this Senate. I can understand you being sensitive on that issue and trying to pass it away. But, Senator Kernot, that is the issue which we now have to turn our minds to in this Senate to get this budget through and we look forward to your support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, is it not true that this 30 per cent of budget outlays is your agenda and plan? These are your conservative state premier mates. It has nothing to do with the Senate. This is your ideological high ground that you were going to deliver on. What is plan B? Is not Jeff Kennett's call for all‐party tax reform at the heart of this impasse? Is this government going to address Jeff Kennett's call for all‐party talks on future tax reform? But what is plan B if you do not get this through next Monday?

—Madam President, I am at a loss to see how that could follow on from the first question. Senator Kernot, the public gave you a message to give this government a fair go. That is the message which this government has given you and that is plan A—and over the next three or four weeks, you will have that chance. The public are turning their minds to you and they were very unimpressed with the Democrat performance in Lindsay because they felt that you were being a little bit obstructionist, Senator Kernot, and we look for a more positive attitude from you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Do you recall justifying to the estimates committee your government's decision to exclude Commonwealth seniors health card holders from eligibility for hearing services on the basis of the savings this would generate? If I can remind you, you said:

QUESTION.PARA: decisions had to be taken that were not always the ones we would have chosen to take. Nevertheless this was one area where there were some savings to be made and we regretfully took them.

Are you aware that your department has now indicated in response to a question given on notice at estimates that there were no savings from this measure? How do you explain this discrepancy, minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have lived long enough to know that, if Senator Mackay asks a question like that, it is best to go and get the detail of a response for her because I cannot be sure that the facts on which she is relying are the true and the entire facts.
—It will be hard to get a supplementary out of that.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I appreciate that you may have to go and look at it, but might I suggest that in future you would better off leaving all the answers to your departmental officials, who clearly know something about what is going on in your portfolio.
—That is not a supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. I refer the minister to the recent legal challenge by the Federal Airports Corporation to the listing of high conservation bushland and wetlands at the Perth airport on the Register of the National Estate. What is the basis for the legal challenge? Does it have your support? Does it have the support of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development or other cabinet ministers? Does the minister consider it appropriate that the Federal Airports Corporation is taking this action during the leasing process for Perth airport, and does he consider that such an action could be seen as an attempt to maximise the revenue from the lease of the Perth airport at the expense of the important bushlands and wetlands that are contained within the boundaries of the airport land?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the action that has been taken by the FAC, which has submitted an application for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. Basically, they are arguing that the AHC has in some ways made a determination in contravention of its obligations under the act. As I understand it, it is quite complex and there are a number of different grounds for the action as alleged.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that it is not appropriate for it to be supported by any minister, and certainly not by me. In fact, whilst it is their right to bring the action, I somewhat regret it. It is unhelpful in the sense that it ends up costing the taxpayer money—and others as well. I would have liked to think that bodies such as the FAC and the AHC could find an amicable resolution to any difficulties they might have.

To date, they have not and, as you know, because I would like to see a constructive resolution rather than a litigated resolution, I have asked Senator Campbell, my parliamentary secretary, to communicate with the parties and, with the provision of his good offices, to see whether there is a way forward, short of this matter having to be concluded through the courts. Such a way forward would of course have to protect the natural heritage values which have been recognised by the AHC and for which the nomination was accepted for listing.
I know you know it, Senator Margetts, because I know you and Senator Campbell and conservation groups have visited the airport together—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the member for Swan.

—And the member for Swan as well—and have looked at the conservation values that we are seeking to protect. It is just a matter of our working through this sensibly and rationally to see whether we can sort it out, short of an ultimate litigated outcome.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Senator Hill may recall that, during the debate on the Airports (Transitional) Bill, Senator Campbell indicated that he understood that the bushland had been recognised by the Australian Heritage Commission and listed on the national register. It was indicated at that time that there were problems in management. Does that not justify the concerns that I expressed at that time that not only did there need to be statements in the bill about the environment; there needed to be a commitment from who ever holds the lease, whoever runs the airports, to manage the area? What we are seeing is the exact opposite: an attempt to downgrade the listing and then perhaps have that area used for other purposes. Is this not exactly the argument that was badly countered during the debate on the bill?

—I regret that I do not remember the whole of Senator's Margetts's contribution to that debate. But the principle is that we want to preserve the conservation values whilst at the same time recognising the airport as a major commercial facility. In fact, one step forward that we are seeking to take is the negotiating of a management agreement whereby both objectives can be achieved. If Senator Campbell is successful in bringing that to pass, then it will be something that I am sure that we all would applaud.

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, representing the Attorney‐General. Minister, was Justice Michael Kirby of the High Court correct when he said that studies showed Australia was already, by world standards, a low spending country in the field of legal assistance? Was he correct when he said that Australia spends $13 per person per year on legal assistance as compared with New Zealand spending $16, Canada $18, the Netherlands $22 and the United Kingdom $65? Was he correct when he said that the withdrawal of this type of funding would cause attacks on the legal system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan, Justice Kirby's comments have not been drawn to my attention. I did, incidentally, see him briefly in India participating in a legal conference, which was part of the Australia‐India New Horizons conference that so much news has been generated about and so many questions asked of Senator Alston yesterday. I take the opportunity to point out to you how successful the education section of that conference was.

ANSWER.PARA: I did not have a long discussion with him there. He did not raise these remarks. I am unaware of them. I do not know if he made them before he went to India or when he came back. But since you, Senator McKiernan, in your committee work, are, generally speaking, almost as charming as Senator Cooney, I will get you an answer quickly too.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, the Australian community is deeply concerned about the state of the environment and is getting more and more involved in hands‐on activities to restore the health of our natural heritage. This is evidenced by the growing number of people involved in voluntary community conservation groups. Will the minister inform the Senate of environmental remediation programs sponsored by his portfolio to assist these groups to monitor and repair our environment; the estimated number of people participating in those programs; and the funding provided to those programs in the 1996‐97 budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to recognise the unsung heroes of the environment: the literally hundreds of thousands of Australians who are out there making the difference. What they do will far exceed that which is done by both governments and the high profile conservation organisations. It is something that has occurred particularly in the last decade or so and something that I think in the end will make the difference.

ANSWER.PARA: It was only a week or so ago that we concluded Waterwatch week, which basically involved community groups, quite often school children, joining together to monitor the state of their streams and waterways and if they find any problems they engage local government and others to seek remedial action. I understand that, although that program started only some three years ago, there are about 35,000 Australians active now on a continuing basis in that program. That will help make the difference. I was pleased to announce funding of just over $1 million from the Commonwealth to facilitate their work—`facilitate' is the right word because we help fund facilitators to ensure that the maximum benefit is obtained from the work they do.

BREAK.PARA: But other programs are just as good. The coastcare program—another community action program—is estimated to have engaged some 144,000 Australians over the last year. It was found that the Fortech review of remanent vegetation this year and the save the bush program involved in excess of 85,000 Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, another one.

—Senator Carr, you might not think it is important but we think the community that is out there working to restore the health of the environment is something vitally important and is something that ought—
—Put it in the budget. Put your money where your mouth is.

—to be applauded by both sides in this chamber—by Labor as well, Senator Carr. Some 85,000 have worked through the save the bush program in the last year; another 65,000 have worked through the one billion trees program. There are hundreds of thousands of Australians going out there and contributing to improve the health of their environment.

BREAK.PARA: Yes, it is true that the Commonwealth government is supporting these programs financially. I remind you that in this last budget we announced funding for the national corridors of green program of $1.36 million; the River Murray corridors of green, $200,000; the urban forest program, $350,000; save the bush, $1.5 million; one billion trees, $1 million; and coastcare, some $3 million. We will do our bit; we will provide what funding support we can. We will provide a lead, but really the community picking up the challenge, working as a community in small groups together, working on land degradation, working on the health of coasts and streams, working on salinity problems, is what really will make the difference to improving an environment that has been allowed to become degraded and that needs much greater community support to return it to the state of health that we would all wish to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, given your answer to yesterday's question about housing affordability that private sector investment is dependent upon the progress of the COAG reforms on housing, were there any tangible outcomes at last Friday's meeting of Australian housing ministers or is it true, according to an article in today's Australian Financial Review , that Victoria proposed a radically different model, New South Wales wants a moratorium on changing the existing system and Queensland and Western Australia are particularly opposed to the private rental aspect of the reforms? Has you housing policy process ground to a halt?

—I am grateful for the opportunity to answer that, Senator, because obviously the author of that article is practising for the Miles Franklin. There is not very much truth in the entire article. I do not really think it deserves a detailed answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Do you at least have any time frame for the resolution of the impasse between the Commonwealth and the states on housing policy? Can you tell the Senate when exactly a housing agreement will be achieved and how will these unfortunate delays impact upon the framework of the 1997-98 and 1998-99 budgets? Are you reconsidering, for example, whether the states should be provided with further capital funds for public housing construction after 1998, extending existing housing arrangements for another year?

—The housing reforms are a cooperative exercise between the territories, the states and the Commonwealth. Perhaps that message has not yet got through to the opposition, who started the reforms. It will depend very much on the cooperation of all parties to achieve the results because we are not imposing a solution from Canberra, Senator West. As most Australians do not like the solutions that your government imposed from Canberra when you were in government, we are taking a more cooperative approach. So the solutions to housing reform will be very much dependent upon the support of the states. I might say that the housing ministers continue to sign on to communiques and resolutions—one of which was released after the meeting last Friday. We all want to achieve housing reform.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Social Security. I draw the minister's attention to her government's proposal to reduce the maximum rent allowance for single people by one-third when they are in shared accommodation. Can the minister advise how many disabled persons receiving the maximum rent assistance who are also accommodated in shared housing will be affected? By reducing the rent assistance to these people by $24.60 per fortnight, how much does the government expect to save? What are the unmet housing needs for people with disabilities and how will this measure assist in meeting those needs? Did the minister consult with disability consumer groups on this matter?
—I can answer the last one. The answer is no.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the last one—which Senator West is so ready to answer for me—this was a budget measure and, therefore, in the normal process there is not a great deal of consultation no matter who is in government. As far as the details and statistics are concerned, I will get them for you and bring them back to you.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to make it clear that the structure of rent assistance, until now—and still now—is such that couples receive considerably less rent assistance than do single people who are sharing. With the reforms to rent assistance proposed in the budget, two single people sharing will still be something like $30 better off than a couple in the same circumstances. It is not a harsh measure. It might be a measure that people are not keen about but it is—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a harsh measure. You should go and ask the people affected.

—If it is a harsh measure, one has to ask why the previous government did not do something about relative rent assistance rates between singles and couples. I recognise that people with disabilities usually—not always, but frequently, certainly—have greater need of public housing than private housing because of the need to change houses to accommodate their disabilities. That is a very important consideration which is being taken into account in the negotiations between the states and the Commonwealth in the housing reforms. It is intended by the Commonwealth that these reforms should go ahead with continuing strong consultation by the Commonwealth, state and territory governments with organisations like the disability ones.

—I thank the minister for her answer. I have had representations from groups like Unicare in Brisbane, which are very concerned because they have assisted in the deinstitutionalisation of many of these people and moved them into group homes where they provide assistance on a very tight budget. It really would be a problem for them to have any reduction in that assistance. I wonder whether you might advise the Senate whether you are able to consult with groups such as Unicare in Brisbane?

—I have not met with Unicare in Brisbane. My door is very widely open to all community groups that have an interest in this portfolio. I might say that the women's organisations are now saying that this government is giving greater access to them than they ever achieved under the previous government, and the same thing goes for welfare organisations, for which I have an abiding interest and concern. I think you will find that, if I am not available, my parliamentary secretary or staff in my office are available. But there is a continuing availability of this government to listen, which is more than you can say for the arrogance that preceded us.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Minister, is it a fact that the Prime Minister confirmed today that the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet received $50,000 as head of a Victorian transport committee? Is it also a fact that Mr Max Moore‐Wilton received $30,000 as chairman of Southern Hydro? Can you inform the Senate whether the chairman's fees of Southern Hydro have been increased by at least $10,000 since Mr Max Moore‐Wilton was appointed chair? Is this acceptable behaviour from a person who is heading up the Commonwealth public service?

—I do not know the detail, and I do not think that you would expect me to know the aspect relating to Southern Hydro and whether fees have increased. But I will take that on notice and seek the information you have sought. In relation to the issue of principle, I understand that disclosure was made to the Prime Minister—
—Did he declare his conflict of interest before he started?
—He has three jobs.
—Senator Hill, resume your seat. There are too many interjections on my left. Senator Hill, I do not know whether you have finished your answer but—
—He sat down.
—I asked him to sit down while the chamber came to order. Senator Hill?
—I was saying that I understand that disclosure was made to the Prime Minister, and that is what counts.

—I have a supplementary question, Madam President. This is a serious matter and I ask the minister: can you assure the Senate that Mr Max Moore‐Wilton's multiple sources of remuneration do not create a serious conflict of interest? I further ask: is Mr Max Moore‐Wilton a suitable person to be investigating conflict of interest among ministers in the Howard government?
—In my judgment, he is particularly suitable and able to hold down that position. Obviously, if he made full disclosure to the Prime Minister, the circumstances were accepted.

—My question is addressed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, is it true that industry figures have criticised the former Labor government for its inaction over issues related to the information and com munications revolution? Can you please advise the Senate what this government is doing to fill the policy vacuum that was left so embarrassingly by the previous government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is true that there has been significant criticism of the previous administration's tokenistic approach to the challenges of the information revolution. There are so many things that need to be addressed—on‐line services, multimedia applications, the challenges of electronic commerce. All of these things were in desperate need of attention over the last couple of years. It is fair to say that Jeff Kennett, as Premier of Victoria, has led the way in this country, until now, by encouraging the establishment of something in excess of 400 multimedia software developers in the Southbank precinct in Melbourne. That is why—
—Is that funded by the Commonwealth government?

—No, funded by the Victorian government and substantially by the private industry. It is a critically important area. That is why we established an Information Policy Advisory Council, which had its first meeting last Monday, to bring together leaders in the industry and the community to discuss the future of our country in the information age. The main focus of the meeting was not only a discussion on the overall ongoing role of IPAC and its priorities for action but also a concentration on practical outcomes.

ANSWER.PARA: I have already given the council two references. The first relates to the investigation of on-line infrastructure and services development in rural and regional Australia. There is growing demand for on-line services and new network technologies in regional Australia. Telstra is upgrading its nationwide network and a growing number of Internet service providers are operating services to non-metropolitan users. Nonetheless, rural industry and users continue to be constrained in their access to services at affordable prices.

IPAC will also investigate the deployment of information and communications services and technologies with the services sector of the economy. It will investigate and advise the government on the implications of network services and technologies for service areas on factors affecting their take-up by businesses within the sector, and steps which the government can take to remove impediments to the deployment of such services on the most productive basis.

I am very much looking forward to an early report from that committee, which is being very ably chaired by Dr Terry Cutler. He has provided a number of landmark reports, particularly Commerce in content, which was available to the previous government some 18 months to two years ago. It is therefore very disturbing that Dr Cutler's introductory remarks to IPAC on Monday night effectively commenced with the following address to the members, who are a very illustrious group:
To begin with, we need to have a sense of urgency. We need to make up for 18 months of lost time. Our predecessor body NISC—
that is Mr Keating's National Information Services Council—
met only once and did nothing. Many, many people have commented to me that we have to make up for lost time.

It is an absolute tragedy that even someone like Mr Keating, who pretended to have an interest in this subject, was only prepared to go to the point of establishing a committee as pure window-dressing and then to have no follow-up at all. To the extent that Mr Keating was not able to be involved, we had Mr Lee who chaired the telecommunications advisory panel. But whenever you asked any members of that panel how it was going, they said, `Mr Lee never says anything.' When Bill Gates was out here about 18 months ago, he spent about an hour with Mr Keating. On his way out he said to one of his aids, `Who was that little boy sitting in the corner who did nothing?' The bloke said, `Don't worry about him. He is just Michael Lee, the Minister for Communications.'

The fact is you are a standing joke in this area. You have no commitment to the electronic age. You are not interested in multimedia services. You were not prepared to bring together a body of leading talents in the industry. We are. We only have to have two meetings to double your achievement. The second meeting will be held very shortly. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Medical Association: Medicare Provider Numbers

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Why has the AMA and its national representative on training been prevented by the government members from addressing the public hearing of the community affairs committee on Medicare provider numbers; further, what has Dr Wooldridge done to encourage the coalition members to allow the AMA to be heard?
—Do you like this, Meg?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party being the advocates for the AMA is a lovely turn of events. I think the answer to this question is best given by reading the letter which the chairman of the community affairs committee, Senator Knowles, sent to Dr Woollard, the Federal President of the Australian Medical Association. She says:

ANSWER.PARA: Further to our conversation of today's date I thought it necessary to confirm to you the reasons for the Committee's decision to, on this rare occasion, not include the Australian Medical Association on the list of those who will provide formal oral evidence to the inquiry.

The Committee considered that the submission provided by the AMA was particularly comprehensive and that the AMA has stated its position clearly and unequivocally since the announcement relating to Medicare Provider Numbers.

The Committee therefore believed that it was important (within the limited time available) to learn the views of other interested parties whose opinions have not had such extensive coverage. (The Committee has four bills before it for consideration in two days and has already sought the unusual step of seeking permission of the Senate to meet while the Senate is sitting, to accommodate the workload).

Because of the time constraints [the Deputy Chairman] Senator Lees offered representatives of the AMA an opportunity to provide one witness who could appear before the Committee together with, for example, the NSW Resident Medical Officers Association.
I see Senator Lees nodding in agreement. It goes on:

BREAK.PARA: That offer was refused on the basis that if the AMA could not appear separately it was not interested in appearing at all.
The Committees of the Parliament are forced every day to make such decisions which inevitably result in the exclusion of people who would wish to appear.

The views of the AMA have always been appreciated and therefore if you have additional material you wish to place before the Committee then the Committee would, I am sure, be very pleased to accept a supplementary submission.
That is a letter dated 5 November from Senator Knowles, the chairman of the community affairs committee to the Federal President of the AMA. I think it speaks for itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Do you, Minister, consider that it is appropriate for the chair of the committee, Senator Knowles, to attempt to prevent the AMA from addressing the committee on this particular matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tierney for his question. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Carr this day, relating to the public relations activities of Telstra.

Three weeks ago, Elaine Brown, administrator of the war room at Telstra, in the commercial and consumer division, wrote to a series of executives outlining Telstra's strategy for public opinion manipulation and the identification of a number of journalists that were causing Telstra a few difficulties. She also identified critics and sought to marginalise critics of Telstra and in so doing establish not just a small question arising out of discussion about the Internet services but an opening of a window on the way in which Telstra is currently operating. It is operating in such a manner as to facilitate the government's political priorities and its political objectives while, at the same time, advancing its business interests in the lead‐up to privatisation.

Everything that occurs in Telstra in the current environment is aimed at the ultimate objective of privatisation. Already, without a motion being passed by this Senate and without a law being enacted by this parliament, the actions of this government are distorting all the actions of Telstra throughout its every business unit. This document highlights that all actions of a politically sensitive nature now have to be cleared with the minister's office. This document highlights the fact that, in the run‐up to privatisation, quite clearly they are concerned about the opposition. It says:

In the run‐up to privatisation the opposition will be seeking opportunities to demonstrate that Telstra's behaviour as a fully commercially focused entity will place commercial before public interest. It is therefore imperative that Telstra advises the minister's office in advance of initiatives that may be politically sensitive.

What we see from these documents is that, quite clearly, Telstra has entered into the political debate. A publicly funded corporation, run for public benefit, is involving itself in the political debate on the issues that are before this parliament in such a way as just not to present a public interest but to present the commercial interest of the statutory corporation and in a manner that seeks to identify critics, to marginalise them and to highlight—in a politically unethical manner—devices by which public opinion can be manipulated and the interests of Telstra and the government can be advanced in so doing.

It just so happens that they have identified four specialist journalists in terms of this particular document. John Hilvert of the Australian, Peter Young of Computer World, Charles Wright of the Australian Financial Review and Sue Lowe of the Sydney Morning Herald have been identified. This document clearly sets out the strategies that are being pursued, seeking to isolate, to marginalise, to identify what they regard and this government obviously regard as unreasonable critics and to specify manners by which their opinions can be marginalised and corralled in such a way as to advance the interests of Telstra.

This document clearly demonstrates that Telstra has now entered the political debate in a manner that will seek to advance their position, often while inaccurate and misleading propaganda is being presented. Public attention is being diverted away from the issues which go to the effect of the business operations of Telstra, particularly within the context of privatisation. We are concerned that this now follows a pattern. We have already seen, in terms of the Senate inquiry, project mercury being established and followed through. We have also seen project straw man with regard to the research laboratories in Melbourne. We now have the war room.

A report in this morning's Herald-Sun by Clinton Porteous reveals that a secret strategy to counter the media and industry criticism has been established. A war room has been established to manage information and to seek to distort it in such a way as to protect the government from any action that might surprise the government during the Telstra privatisation debate. This article identifies that the war room is expecting not only to not achieve a full 100 per cent cessation of hostilities between Telstra and its Internet service providers but also to manipulate opinion in such a way as to marginalise any critics. It is singling out and diverting attention away from the key issues. For a public corporation to be involved in such practices is in itself totally inappropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Carr regarding the answer given by Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, to him at question time today. First, it was clear from the minister's answer that he either did not know, or he made out he did not know, of the existence of this document, which has come into the possession of the opposition and is now being made available. It is an interesting document. It is dated 22 October and is headed `From Elaine Brown, War Room Administrator'. If you were dealing with the Department of Defence, you might have a war room, or if you were an aficionado for the movie Dr Strangelove , you may have one. However, there really is something culturally wrong in an organisation such as Telstra, which is government owned, creating something called a war room and naming an officer as the administrator of it. It gives quite an unhappy presentation to the public about how Telstra sees the way it should handle its public relations.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Carr said, over the last seven or eight months since the new government came into office, we have had these new developments of Project Mercury and Project Straw Man. They are projects aimed at overcoming a difficulty or promoting a new arrangement that advantages Telstra. They want to advantage Telstra by achieving the political, ideological end of this government, which is the privatisation of Telstra.

The document, though mentioning issues relating to the Internet, is really about marginalising those who criticise Telstra. Telstra may be somewhat successful, because they are a very big player in the communications network of Australia. They hold around 90 per cent of the business.

Senator Alston would say that that is what you get from a government-owned institution. He is the minister. He has the power to direct. You would have thought he would set out the ethics for the operation of Telstra when they start developing these sorts of projects. But, no—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are briefing him.

—At the moment, they are briefing him. The document identifies the key stakeholders as the minister's office and Mr Paul Fletcher, the person who should be contacted and involved in discussions over Telstra strategy. This means that the minister's office is directly involved in commercial activities, which affects relations with journalists. You cannot convince this opposition that there is not a political intent in the involvement of the minister's office in these arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: If the minister were open and transparent, he would knock on the head these sorts of projects and say to Telstra, `Get on with developing your commercial interests in an open and transparent way with reasonable and decent ethics.' That is not what this minister has been about. He has been happy to be involved in the discussion about this. Certainly his office has been identified as being involved.

BREAK.PARA: This is a further justification for maintaining Telstra in public ownership. If Telstra were privatised, with its dominant market power being around 90 per cent, and let loose with this sort of approach to running its business in Australia without reference to the Australian public other than through the Stock Exchange, the national interest would be seriously weakened. That is one reason why we strongly support Telstra being publicly owned. Because it has 90 per cent of the business of telecommunications in Australia, it ought to be responsible to the people of Australia.

Telstra should not get involved in the sort of grubby exercise that is outlined in this document, which refers to a war room administrator. It should not finger particular journalists who have to be lobbied or, if they are not successfully converted to Telstra's view, marginalised. It is not an acceptable level of ethics for any organisation in Australia, particularly for a government-owned enterprise. We believe that this is one case where the minister should openly state that this is unacceptable and tell Telstra to get on with the job of running a successful telecommunications business in an open and transparent way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support my colleague Senator Carr in taking note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) at question time today. It is quite interesting to see this document that Senator Carr has circulated, because it really confirms all the fears about the privatisation of Telstra that have been expressed by both me and my colleagues in this chamber. It also expresses all the fears and concerns that were quite well articulated in the inquiry report that was completed only a few weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one issue that really needs addressing straight up, and that is whether the minister's ignorance of this issue is in fact feigned or real. This begs the question. The document states that the briefing to the key government and regulatory authorities, which are specifically listed in the document as including the minister's office as well as the ACCC, the broadcasting authority, and the department, all occurred in mid‐September. I put on the record that there is still a question hanging over whether or not the minister's office has had the brief.

That takes me to the next point, which is if the minister's office has had a brief, has it taken the time and the opportunity to fill the minister in on these very important issues. My colleague Senator Schacht highlighted, quite correctly, what sort of culture has been bred within Telstra. Quite obviously, Telstra is in the complete mind‐set of moving towards full privatisation. You will notice that this document does not refer to partial privatisation; it refers to privatisation.

Certainly, this is nothing new to us, as members of the Labor opposition. It just confirms the position we have taken on it. But it really exposes the position taken by the government, that the partial privatisation is in fact, as we know, the first step to full privatisation.

There are a couple of other issues that are worthy of extracting and highlighting from this document. With regard to this Internet strategy, Telstra not only is the provider of the wholesale bandwidth of the Internet service providers but also it has been positioning itself for quite some time as a retail provider. This document represents the re‐positioning they have had to do since they first got such a negative response in taking on the Internet service providers generally. It is a very interesting point that the ACCC is so high up on their list of briefings. In fact, straight after the minister's office you have the Department of Communications and the Arts. One would hope that they were considered important enough to be briefed.

The next one in line is in fact the ACCC. The ACCC would need to be dealt with pretty early on if this strategy were to be implemented, because it raises very serious issues about how Telstra positions itself with respect to competition policy. To have what is a public entity in the considerable position of market domination now manoeuvring itself in anticipation of privatisation to become not only the wholesale provider of bandwidth to Internet service providers but in fact a retail competitor of such services, the endorsement, acknowledgment or approval of the ACCC is in fact quite fundamental to this whole strategy. This whole strategy, to me, is about Telstra positioning itself to make money, to make a profit, and to define and secure the market share of Internet usage.

It is no surprise to anyone in this chamber that Internet usage is on an exponential growth curve. Whoever positions themselves in quite a secure way over the next short period of time, particularly in the lead‐up to the July 1997 changes, will do so in the knowledge that they will secure a solid income stream from their particular service provider.

So, back to the question of where this leaves the Internet service providers, the current ISPs. The bottom line is that Telstra has got these service providers, these businesses that have set themselves up to on‐sell bandwidth, where they want them. This is unfortunate for them, and it is unfortunate that the privatisation of Telstra will lead to the reduction of competition in that sector. (Time expired)
