QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Medical Association: Medicare Providers Numbers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator Neal today, relating to the appearance of representatives of the Australian Medical Association before the Community Affairs Legislation Committee.

There was some mirth expressed by Senator Newman in response to this question on the basis that she seemed to think it was somehow humorous that the opposition, the Australian Labor Party, should defend the right of the AMA to speak to a committee in relation to a matter that they were concerned about. Frankly, I find that amusement really quite out of place. It certainly has been the view of the ALP, whether or not they agreed with the views of those members of the community, that they should always have the opportunity to address an issue that is going to affect them quite severely, and certainly this is the case in this instance.

The Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, which is presently being considered by the committee, has a major effect not only on medical practitioners at large but particularly in relation to medical graduates who have undertaken their course and who, in future, may well have their right to practice adversely affected by the changes that are contained in this bill. I am certain that a number of practising doctors in this chamber, on both sides, would be very aware of that and would certainly be very aware of the anger and upset in the community, particularly by those trainee doctors and medical undergraduates. In fact, I understand that at the moment—and this has been happening throughout the week—industrial action is being taken in a number of places to express those views.

In light of the very strong feelings that have been expressed through this industrial action and by way of submissions that a number of people made to me, I feel very strongly that it should have been appropriate for the committee to allow the AMA to address it. I was provided with a copy of the letter that was sent by the chairman of the committee to the AMA. I was grateful to receive that. But, in my view, it is not sufficient or satisfactory to say that an exhaustive submission in a written form to a committee is a satisfactory substitution for the opportunity for a group to put, in person and orally, their views and to express strongly their emotions about how it is going to affect them.

There has been a lot of dispute and different views expressed about the number of medical graduates who are going to be affected by this change. In my view, medical graduates are going to be affected. The change to this legislation means that graduates will no longer be able to do their intern year, then go out to practice and receive a Medicare provider number until they have done a general practitioner course, which will take them, in most cases, a number of years.

I suppose on the face of it that is appealing. No-one would argue that further training is inappropriate or would not assist patients at large, but the difficulty is that most medical graduates, after having spent six years training, will not be able to receive any remuneration unless they are able to obtain a position in a hospital. A position may or may not be available to them in their area.

I am of the view that these changes are particularly unfair in that they take effect immediately. The changes are not deferred until present medical graduates have come through and received their provider numbers. They take effect immediately. Just for one moment put yourself in the position of medical undergraduates who have done, say, five years study and are waiting to do their intern year next year and suddenly discover that before they can practise they may have to do somewhere between three and five years further training.

There are three areas where it has particular impact. One relates to graduates who may want to supplement their incomes while they do their training. That is quite a common occurrence. They may fill in in out of hours clinics or with a doctor who is going away on holidays. They may also do late night sections. They cannot do that under the new regime. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond not to the substance of the legislation that Senator Neal was just talking about but to the question that Senator Neal put to Senator Newman at question time. It goes to the heart of why the Australian Medical Association was not on this occasion called to give evidence before the Community Affairs Legislation Committee. I have been on this committee for eight or 10 years—I am not too sure of the exact time.

PARA.BREAK: This would be one of the rare occasions, if not the only occasion, that the Australian Medical Association has not been called to give evidence on an issue that relates to the medical profession. The interesting thing is that, on this occasion, we have so many submissions in relation to not only this bill but also the other three bills that the committee is addressing in the next two days—and all the bills have been referred to the commit tee by the opposition parties—that we are trying to accommodate as many views as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: I spoke to Dr Woollard, the National President of the AMA, for 28 minutes yesterday. I told him that the reason we did not include the AMA on this rare occasion was that their submission was exceedingly comprehensive. It is interesting that Senator Neal is actually leaving the chamber and is not interested to hear the explanation that I am giving. The explanation is particularly significant. I have to admit that Dr Woollard failed to accept that explanation. As I said to him and as I said in the letter, the AMA provided a very comprehensive and detailed submission. There is no question about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the key union. They are the main representative body for doctors.
—Would you mind stopping chirping like a canary, Senator West. You really sound like a chicken in a chicken coop.
—That shows the respect you hold them in.
—Order! Disregard the interjections, Senator Knowles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —As I explained to Dr Woollard yesterday, the fact remains that his submission was exceedingly good and his views and the views of the AMA are hardly unknown to the committee. Therefore, the committee made a judgment that, given the limited time, we would actually seek the opinions of those that were less well known to the committee so that we had the broadest opinion on which to base the committee's decision and judgment. It was the view of the committee that it was important to hear as many voices as possible. To ensure that that is possible, we will hear from all types of students who may be affected, whether they be resident medical officers, doctors in training or others. There are so many who want to be heard.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, I have probably had six or eight phone calls from other organisations that also wish to be heard. Interestingly enough, the Australian Medical Association is the only one that has effectively said to me, `We will take this further and you mark my words.' The others have accepted the rationale that we cannot hear everyone and that it is important that we get the broadest cross-section of opinion possible.

I am hoping that the Australian Medical Association, in the light of day, will see that this is one rare occasion when they have not been called. That does not mean to say that the committee will not take into consideration their excellent submission or the views that they have repeatedly expressed in every section of the media since the announcement regarding Medicare provider numbers.

It is unquestionably a very representative body of the medical profession. It is in no way intended as a slight upon them in any way, shape or form. It is simply a fact that the opposition parties have seen fit to put bill after bill before one committee. There are four pieces of legislation for the committee to consider in two days. We cannot hear everyone. We are seeking to get the broadest possible representation and consultation available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two points that are raised in this matter. The first relates to how a committee should be run. I think that is a matter for each committee to decide. I do not want to go into the pros and cons of what has happened on this occasion. However, having listened to Senator West, I think she was saying this: on a matter such as this, where medical students and medical people generally are very much affected, the AMA, which represents all those groups across the board, would be a good candidate to be considered as to whether or not they ought to give evidence. I leave it at that. I think it would be wrong for me, as a person who believes heavily in the committee system, to interfere in any way with the workings of a committee. I simply translate to the people listening what Senator West was saying.

ANSWER.PARA: There is the issue that has been raised about the provider numbers themselves. I must confess that I have a big personal interest in this matter. The deputy clerk has often said that financial interests are one basis upon which you might have a conflict of interest on things. I think other issues are as well. On this occasion the fact that I have a daughter who is in the middle of the situation that has been created by this legislation is a good illustration of how you can be affected.

Having declared my interest, I think it is a point that ought to be considered very much by all people who are approaching this issue, because the issue on this occasion seems to me to be driven not by interests in people's health, but by interests in the budget's health. This legislation does not prevent any of these people who will be deprived of provider numbers, in circumstances where they otherwise would not have been, from practising. It does not stop them treating people. In other words, it is not legislation which prevents the people it affects from treating patients. What it does is stop those patients claiming back from Medicare what has been charged to them by these people who will now be without provider numbers. That is something that ought to be understood by all those people who are considering this legislation. It is not legislation about health; it is legislation about money.

For that reason this may well have been a bill that could have gone to the finance committee instead of the committee to which it did go. It seems to me to be harsh that the people who will be affected by this financial measure are people who have in no way contributed to the financial problems, such as they are, within the health system. These are young students who have never had the chance to claim on Medicare, so they are being punished, as it were, for what other people have done.

It has been alleged that there have been rorts within the Medicare system. So what do you do? You do not punish those who have committed those rorts; they are left with their provider numbers. You punish the patients who will go to these people who are now coming through and who, until this time, have had the reasonable expectation of getting a Medicare provider number.

I conclude on this point: these people have gone through their courses, they have done their schooling, they have done up to six years of hard, slogging work. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, it is hard, slogging work. At the end of that time, at five minutes to midnight, they are deprived of the expectation which they have reasonably had until now. That is the real problem in all of this.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Community Affairs Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996, together with submissions and transcript of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This report deals with the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996, a bill that gives effect to a large proportion of the social security measures—largely harsh ones—announced by the coalition government in the 1996 budget. As mentioned in the minority report contained in the documents tabled by Senator Knowles, Labor's response to this legislation and, indeed, to all the measures announced in the 1996‐97 budget, is based on how the measures weigh up against three principles: does the measure betray a promise; is it equitable; and does it contribute to national savings?

SPEECH.PARA: When we looked at this bill in detail—particularly at the committee stage—we felt that, in a great many respects, the proposed legislation falls sadly short of meeting these three principles. Not only does it betray many promises, not only is it inequitable, but some of the measures contained within it will certainly not contribute to national savings.

We pointed out in our report that the coalition went to the last election making very strong commitments to the people of Australia. In particular, John Howard promised that his government would protect the poor, the needy and the most vulnerable in our community. This bill includes measures that, far from fulfilling those commitments, specifically harm those whom John Howard singled out for protection. The removal of a massive $1.5 billion over four years from the social security safety net alone underlines that betrayal.

This, we believe, is John Howard's most cynical broken promise because it was a promise that meant so much to the community and so many believed it. We in the Labor Party will not stand by and allow Australians to be betrayed.

Examining the proposed legislation in detail through the committee confirmed that certainly we in the Labor Party are not the only ones who believe that the proposed legislation is not equitable. Submissions received by the committee, and evidence given during the hearings, revealed that there is a great deal of concern in the community about the measures proposed. It was not just the peak groups such as the Australian Council of Social Service and the National Welfare Rights Network who made valuable contributions to the committee. Community neighbourhood centres, concerned citizens and small organisations whose resources are already stretched took the time to write to the committee and make us aware of their concerns.
A concerned individual, Mr Stephen Morrow from Newtown in Sydney, wrote to the committee about the measures affecting unemployed people. He commented:

I understand that this Bill will increase penalties from two weeks to anything up to thirteen weeks, for alleged breaches of the Department of Social Security procedures by recipients of unemployment benefits. I believe this measure is unjust and inappropriate. It will obviously have a significant and serious impact on unemployed people, and it will in turn have a negative impact on the wider community in which these citizens live. The current economic situation means that there are increasing numbers of unemployed people. As a society, we have a moral obligation and an economic interest in ensuring that these people will remain within the bounds of community. The proposed Bill will impoverish these people even further and alienate them from the community. We cannot afford this.
Those are Mr Morrow's comments. I do not think I could have put it any better.

The measures contained in this bill, designed to cut people off payments and reduce their benefits, will have the effect of exiling certain people beyond the bounds of our community, relegating them to destitution and despair. While this may satisfy the ideologically driven Howard government, it will inevitably have a negative impact on the wider community.

The proposed legislation does not reflect a commitment to protect the poor, the needy or the most vulnerable in the community. In fact, it is an attack on many of those people. Many of the measures contained in the proposed legislation will actually worsen the plight of unemployed people and other social security recipients. Rather than addressing the issue of unemployment, the government has chosen to implement measures that will slash the range of benefits to unemployed people and income support recipients more broadly.

BREAK.PARA: As we said in our minority report, the proposed legislation is based on the premise that unemployed people are seeking to rort the system. The reality is that the majority of unemployed people are honest, genuine job seekers. The excessive measures to tighten the activity test and expand the breach provisions, coupled with the abolition or tightening of a number of schemes that actually assisted job seekers, makes this bill very anti‐unemployed. Labor believes that the government's efforts should be devoted to reducing unemployment rather than cutting people off payments. However, this proposed legislation is attempting to do just that.

There is very little in the proposed legislation that the Australian community can be happy about. The concerns raised in many submissions to the committee have not been taken on board in the report. For this reason, Labor felt it was important to submit a minority report, and these views were shared by the Australian Democrats.

Labor is determined to amend portions of the bill to reflect a commitment to equity and to attempt to fulfil John Howard's commitment to protect the poor, the needy and the most vulnerable in our community. Labor cannot and will not stand by and allow the most vulnerable in our community to pay the price for the coalition's ideological obsessions. I thank the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 5 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the bill as a whole and Senator Margetts's amendment No. 5 to government amendment No. 19.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —When we concluded last evening, I was in the middle of quoting from the Labor document Working Nation at page 33 and I continue:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a key element in the Government's strategy for achieving its overall objectives for enterprise bargaining and industrial relations reform . . .
This bill, I am sure the government will be horrified to hear me say, is far less radical in these respects than Labor's proposals with a much more extensive list of award matters.

It is a bit rich for the Labor Party to stand up and talk about how far awards have been stripped back when their own long‐term plan for the labour market had this clear and public intention. As I outlined earlier to the Labor ranks, it is the implementation that may differ; it is certainly not the intention between the two sides of the chamber.

This amendment which the government and Democrats have put, to which there are opposing amendments, is particularly important; it is the most important in this schedule. It does a number of things to change the content of awards. The government and Democrat amendment No. 19 firstly expands the list of allowable award matters in 89A(2) to expressly include skill‐based career paths, rest breaks, notice periods, variation of hours, superannuation and outworkers.
Secondly, it further expands the operation of allowable matters in 89A(5) to pick up incidental matters necessary but not essential for the effective operation of the award.

Thirdly, it clearly ensures that the commission has the power to set minimum consecutive hours that a part‐time worker can work and the regularity of such hours, thereby preventing the further casualisation of part‐time work.

Fourthly, it allows arbitration outside allowable matters in 89A(6) for exceptional matters. The combined effect of these changes is to broaden the powers of the commission enormously and to ensure that the commission has sufficient power to prevent workers being disadvantaged in a harsh or unjust manner.

The list of allowable matters will now clearly pick up all important aspects of hours of duty, skill development and career paths and superannuation. The coverage of superannuation by awards may be reviewed again next year but only if the government's freedom of choice legislation clearly guarantees that industry super funds will not be undermined and that workers will not be made worse off under the new legislation.

Mention was made of superannuation. I am glad that Senator Sherry is in the chamber because this is his area of particular expertise. The Democrats have persuaded the government to include superannuation as an allowable award matter. We have provided a letter to the government outlining our position on superannuation. That letter has been released publicly and I would like to refer briefly to it.

The Democrats have said that we can see some merit in having one piece of legislation dealing with superannuation. The situation where the first three per cent of compulsory super is award based and the other six per cent is by superannuation guarantee charge legislation is untidy. I do not think it is radical to state that we would be prepared to review this.

But we then go on in our letter to outline the preconditions the government will need to meet for such a piece of legislation to get our support. Firstly, it must ensure that workers are not worse off. That affects, for instance, the award regulation of casual workers earning less than $450 a month or $900 a month under the coalition's policy.

Secondly, the legislation, particularly if it includes freedom of choice provisions or retirement savings accounts, should not be used to undermine industry funds. The Democrats are strong supporters of the industry funds which we believe provide good value for money for most award employees. Much of the argument which the AIRC hears about superannuation at present is about which union preferred fund super will be sent to.

We make it clear in our letter that if agreement is reached on these issues, we will support the removal of superannuation from awards simply because it will no longer be necessary. The award coverage of superannuation ceased to be comprehensive in 1991 when the then ALP government moved to circumvent the 1991 national wage case outcome they did not agree with by implementing it in legislation. It was the ALP which chose to move superannuation advancement out of awards into legislation in 1991.

The Democrats supported the passage of the SGC legislation in 1992 because we felt that compulsory savings were essential to increase our declining national savings rate. The main people disadvantaged by the repeal of award super clauses would have been those exempted from the SGC, that is, those workers earning less than $450 a month.

It is worth noting that, notwithstanding all the grandstanding by Labor in favour of those 20,000 to 50,000 workers affected, these workers were disadvantaged under Labor's super legislation. This is because the fees that super funds were taking out were bigger than the super money going in.

In 1994, the government finally introduced its small amounts legislation, but it was a paltry solution because, instead of moving small amounts to a single super fund with government picking up the administrative costs, it allowed the union sponsored funds to keep the money so long as fees were not higher than interest income. In nominal terms, the accounts do not go backwards, which is an improvement, but, in real terms, they never go forward either. So award based super clauses are not the massive benefit that the ALP claims they are, and we will support retention of those conditions at this time but only because half a bird in the hand is better than none at all.

The other remarks I wish to make about this award section are as follows. In lobbying about this section, unions have sought to pressure us to include issues such as accident make‐up pay, occupational health and safety and staffing. Accident make‐up pay, according to expert legal advice, is clearly covered under 89A(2)(j), allowances, and I will be asking the minister to confirm that interpretation. Occupational health and safety is, according to our advice, more properly dealt with under state law and specific federal laws dealing with workplace health and safety. Most occupational health and safety award clauses, such as protective clothing, would likewise come under 89A(2)(j).

Staffing issues, we believe, will be picked up under the exceptional matters orders. Staffing disputes shall be subject to the agreement in the first instance, as staffing is at first pass an issue for the business to determine. But where staffing is so inappropriate that the workloads are in themselves harsh or unjust, then the commission should have the power to intervene to remove that harshness—and these provisions will allow for that.

The part‐time employment provisions reflect the Democrats' view that part‐time employment must be encouraged. Too many awards contain too many restrictions on part‐time employment. These restrictions were often put in awards as part of bargaining deals, with unions wanting to preserve the bargaining chip of restricting access to part‐time employment to gain future advantages. We believe that the use of access of such work as a bargaining chip is inappropriate—and hence our opposition to quotas and maximum hours. But we do believe that part‐time work does require regulation of minimum hours to prevent employers seeking to casualise part‐time work with a minimum call‐in period. Hours must also be predictable, and we have allowed for that.

We have sought independent legal advice on the scope of section 89A. Two of Australia's most prominent and eminent industrial lawyers have advised us that section 89A clearly covers all of the most important employment conditions of current awards. The clause will give the commission the authority to actually proceed to develop a real and effective award simplification process—and that is something which we support. This amendment is an important part of accelerating Labor's completely log jammed 150A award modernisation process, and I commend it to the Senate.

The exceptional matters orders are a vitally important part of this new clause, and this clause has been inserted to make it quite clear that the commission does have the power to prevent harsh or unjust outcomes. Its arbitral powers will ensure that employers are unable to take advantage of the weak bargaining position of employees to impose their will in a harsh or unjust way.

To access the exceptional matters jurisdiction, there are a number of conditions. The first is that the party has made a genuine attempt to reach agreement. The second is that there is no reasonable prospect of agreement from further conciliation. Those two basically are the pre‐conditions for arbitration now. The third condition is that it is appropriate to settle the matter by arbitration. That means that the commission has a discretion whether to arbitrate or not.

The fourth condition is that the issues involved are exceptional issues. I do not believe that is a major barrier. The Concise Oxford Dictionary defines `exceptional' as `forming an exception'. `Exception' is defined as `thing excepted; thing that does not follow the rule'. The rule in this section is quite clear from 89A(6) where it says that 89A(1) does not exclude an exceptional matter. So the rule which is excepted is the rule that arbitration is limited to section 89A(2), allowable matters.

The fifth condition is clearly the most important one, and that is that a harsh or unjust outcome would apply if the dispute did not include the exceptional matter. And that is really the key criterion in determining whether a party can access this jurisdiction. So it is quite clear that 89A(6) establishes a very important jurisdiction for the commission, a very important protection for avoiding harsh or unjust outcomes; that is a wide and important but still well targeted jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look at occupational health and safety issues as they have been dealt with by the state government in Western Australia, I would have to say that the standards seem to be getting worse and worse. If you do not think it happens, talk to the people in Port Hedland and Karratha. Talk to people driving trucks and providing courier services who are being asked on a regular basis to carry loads that are too great. Talk to people who are being asked to operate equipment in a way that they know is contrary to the operating instructions of that equipment and see if it is not happening on a regular basis throughout the work force in Australia.

Given that, when an accident happens, find out how many employers are willing to accept the responsibility for requiring their workers to work in what is known to be a dangerous way—that is, working with equipment that has worked beyond its ratings, working in a way which short cuts on safety procedures and so on. I talked to a number of people in a number of different areas. The areas that particularly spring to mind are remote rural and regional areas of Australia. In Western Australia, the mining industry also springs to mind.

We are talking about the ability to take legal industrial action on such basic things as vocational training and language and literacy. Included in that is occupational health and safety, the timing and method of the payment of wages, anti‐discrimination measures, equal employment opportunities and affirmative action, minimum ordinary time hours of work, distribution of hours or work, starting times, length of shifts, trade union training and accident make-up pay.

I return to occupational health and safety. This is the opportunity for both the government and the Democrats to retrieve what is an appalling situation. It is absolutely outrageous that workers in Australia may be threatened with fines or worse for taking industrial action for legitimate health and safety disputes. I invite any of them to stand up here and argue why that is a reasonable position to take.

It will be illegal for legitimate health and safety reasons for people to be fined for taking action. Tell me whether or not it is better for them to be injured or killed later or whether it is better and responsible for them to take industrial action when they know they are being asked to do the wrong thing or when they know that the activities in which they are taking place are likely to lead to injuries or accidents even if they fit into whatever codes that exist.

When you think of the Western Australian situation, look at the adds on television. They say, `It is up to you.' Those ads are about putting the onus back on the worker: `It is up to you to say something. It is up to you to take action.'

What a farce it makes if you say, `It's up to you but, if you take action because you know it is dangerous, it will be illegal. You can be fined or worse.' What are we doing to the lives and the health of workers in Australia if this is the situation we are going to be voting on today? Here is an opportunity to change the situation. We have an amendment which puts some of those basic issues back into allowable issues that can be the basis of industrial action.

While I am waiting for an answer, perhaps we could get some definition of what `industrial action' is. It could simply be not doing those things which are dangerous. That, as far as I can see, could be classified as industrial action. Would that be allowable or not allowable? What if workers decide not to do those things which they believe to be dangerous; is that considered to be industrial action? Later on, we will come into the situation of whether people can be paid if they take some sort of industrial action. I am very keen to hear an answer from the minister. I would like Senator Kernot to come down here and exercise her conscience and her free vote and live up to the principles that she has been enunciating around this country time and time again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interesting thing about Senator Sherry's contribution to this debate on his amendment on age discrimination is that, as I recall the debate in most of 1993, I did not hear Senator Sherry get up and speak with the passion he just did on the decision of the previous government, of which he was a member and indeed a parliamentary secretary, when that government decided to do exactly what this bill will do. That is, the Brereton bill came out in 1993 and proscribed age discrimination and then the government amended its own bill to extend this deadline to June 1997, a three‐year period in which most people who had an interest in the debate, and I am sure Senator Stott Despoja—
—That was the Australian Democrats, not us.
—And you did not speak against it, Senator Sherry. Or if you did, it must have been very quietly because I did not hear it. Certainly not with the passion that you just put into it then.
—You weren't in the chamber.

—I might have been sitting in my room listening to you. And, Senator Sherry, when I see you stand in debate I listen. I drop what I am doing and I listen because you make some great contributions, especially on superannuation and those sorts of issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite seriously, this was exactly the decision that was taken by the previous government. The previous government could have made the decision to oppose that three‐year period. Anyone who cares about trying to find an arrangement which will ensure that young people are not further disadvantaged in what has been over a number of years a very weak employment market for young people and that they come to an industrial relations system which is non‐discriminatory was hoping that, over that three‐year period up to 22 June 1997, some replacement that did not expose young people to risks that may be high or may be low could be put in place. That scheme, that framework, has not been found.

There is a lot of evidence out there. The Retail Council of Australia is of course but one voice in the debate, but it estimates that if we got rid of this there would be a couple of hundred thousand young people who would be lost to the industry if those junior wage rates were replaced. They may or may not be right, but I think it is a risk that a lot of people do not want to take.

What we are proposing is to extend these provisions and to constructively ensure that the commission is required to look into this and report to this parliament. We think that is a constructive approach, and that is this government's position. The previous government of course amended its legislation to put this three‐year extension to 22 June 1997 in place.

I remind the members of the previous government, those sitting opposite, members of the Labor Party, that these junior rates awards have been in existence for, I believe, something like 70 years. The previous government, Labor, in power, did nothing, with the exception of the Brereton bill, which was then amended to extend it, to get rid of the junior rates. So it is a little bit rich for Senator Sherry to come in here and start attacking the Democrats or indeed the new government in relation to this issue. We believe we are taking a constructive approach. We believe that having the commission report to the parliament after a comprehensive review of junior rates allows all members of the Senate to make a contribution to how we move forward on this issue.

We ask Senator Sherry to perhaps address the following issue: after 13 years in power, during the last three of which he was on the frontbench, why do they consider that all of a sudden things should change after 22 June 1997? Why does this date have such magical importance, particularly considering that no‐one has proposed any sensible transitional replacement measures? That is exactly what the government, with the support of the Democrats, is proposing with this comprehensive review reporting to the parliament in two years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Sherry with respect to removing the repeal of the amendment that requires the extension of junior rates up until June 1999, as the government and Democrats have put. The Democrats have explicitly agreed to perpetuate junior rates, as opposed to moving to the competency based system that supporting our amendment would result in.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment removes this provision to extend the period of time for junior rates and really highlights the nonsensical approach of the government‐Democrat agreement to just perpetuate junior rates without moving quickly and sensibly to a competency based system—a competency based system that has developed with the cooperation of trade unions and employers over the last decade. It is a competency based system that has had vast resources put into it—whether it be through the industry training advisory boards or through industry itself just getting together with the trade unions and nutting out the best approach to establish comprehensive and meaningful career paths for young people.

The only result of all of this of course is that the credibility of the Democrats in advocating on behalf of youth has been tarnished permanently in the eyes of young people. They have lost for good the opportunity to prove their commitment to young people. I do not think the Liberal Party had any commitment in the first place so they did not have too much to lose. We are opposing this amendment and we will remain the only political party which is not prepared to compromise the principle of a fair day's pay for a fair day's work.

BREAK.PARA: It is not surprising that employers have always used periods of high unemployment such as we have seen to press for reductions in rates of pay and conditions. What we are seeing now is no different. What we are seeing now, with respect to the Liberal approach with Democrat support on this bill, is the pursuance of one of the oldest industrial tricks in the book. What do you take? What is the ultimatum that is being put to the Democrats? Is it less pay, or is it fewer jobs?

I need only refer to some of the comments about the outcomes of this bill and where the jobs are going to be arising out of this. It really raises the question of what comes first. The evidence of the trick that is being played out here is on the basis that quite clearly jobs are not going to come out of this workplace relations legislation, so the threat hanging over the heads of the Democrats and the one that has been used to secure their support is the fact that, if this provision is not removed and if it sticks around and junior rates are perpetuated, then somehow that will mean that employers will not be forced to sack many young people.

So we are not even talking about some advantage to young people and the number of jobs they have available; what we are talking about is a threat by employers in stating their case and their argument that, if this provision is removed, that will result in fewer jobs, because we know that it certainly will not result in more if it stays in. And they have said that.

We have had Ian Macfarlane, the Independent Governor of the Reserve Bank, say that the passage of the bill will not reduce unemployment, that it will not create jobs. That was endorsed by a leading labour market expert, Professor Bob Gregory. He said it in a nutshell, that what the bill really means is much lower pay without extra jobs. Access Economics, who are former Treasury officials and have quite a dry reputation, said that unemployment will go above nine per cent and remain that high into the next century if the workplace relations bill is passed.

Even Mr Howard was forced in the end to concede that employment creation was not an outcome this bill was expected to deliver. Essentially, that reduces this to a question of blackmail, hanging over people's heads the threat that `if you do not support this, the employers have said they will reduce the number of jobs for young people'.

What good is a job if you cannot earn a living wage? That is my question. Young people at the moment are marginalised and forced, in many cases, to work a number of part-time jobs to survive. If they are undertaking tertiary education, they are required to take out part-time employment to supplement their incomes or to get an income. I do not believe this is fair. I do not believe junior rates do equate to a fair day's pay for a fair day's work.

It is not surprising—it was interesting to hear a number of other senators refer to this, as I know Senator Stott Despoja did in her first speech—that young people regard politicians with such distain and cynicism. In the context of this debate we are seeing a fundamental change and, once again, be it young people, women, older people or migrants, certain people are being marginalised.

It was interesting to note that Senator Stott Despoja, in her first speech, raised the notion of intergenerational equity, the notion that, no matter what your age, you have the opportunity to contribute to society in a way that gets a fair return. That is all we are talking about here. It is a matter of principle. Senator Campbell can argue the technical point all he likes but the point here is the principle of choosing whether we, as legislators, perpetuate junior rates which discriminate on the basis of age.

Labor is clearly stating their position on this matter. We will not perpetuate it because it is not fair. We will not perpetuate it because there is an effective alternative. We will not perpetuate it because it is quite clear that this government's agenda goes far beyond some of the idiosyncratic technical arguments they have put in an attempt to substantiate this move. We will not perpetuate it because the line that employers are running—that they will sack young people if junior rates are not perpetuated—is not a good enough reason for doing it.

We all have a responsibility to make the choice of whether we take that view, not only on this technical matter, but also in our broader commitment to young people. Whether they like it or not, the Australian Democrats are faced with a dilemma. For as long as I can remember, they have stood on a platform of youth advocacy. But at the first opportunity to make a tangible difference to young people's ability to earn a living wage—a wage on which they can sustain themselves—at the first opportunity in the area of industrial relations to make a statement, they are choosing not to do it. The Democrats are choosing to back the government on this measure. To me, that does not say much about their commitment to young people. Once again, Labor is left to support what really counts under this legislation.

There is a range of issues here. As I said before, those issues demand consideration of their long‐term effects on working people. But few issues demand comment as much as this issue of the perpetuation of junior rates and age discrimination by the Democrats. I go again to Senator Stott Despoja's first speech—she is a great source of words when it comes to standing up for young people—where she said:
No group in society has been more consistently subject to structural change and its cruel and cutting edge, and for a longer period, than the young.
With respect to the Democrats, here is one opportunity to follow through on those sentiments in a way that will mean something tangible to young people.

In closing, I want to raise one other issue. It has long been a platform of the Democrats that they are independent and not bound by the caucus position. On this issue, where the platform of the Democrats has so strongly been advocacy of young people, they should take advantage of an unbound caucus. Hopefully, with at least five of them, it might make a difference to young people in the years to come because this is the only tangible opportunity that the Democrats have with this bill to do something meaningful for young people. I urge them to take it up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I pick on three things to begin. The first is that we all know that sometimes the louder the voice, the weaker the argument and the weaker the case. I heard that a couple of times. The second thing is that I think I have just witnessed extraordinary Labor opportunism. They have said, `Aha, let's try to get some votes. Never mind the 13 years we were in government. Never mind what we did not do. Here's a chance to get some votes.'

SPEECH.PARA: The third thing I would say—it is not a criticism—is that this bill and the amendments are exceptionally complex. It is quite clear that some senators have not yet got across the full range of the bill. There are many areas on which they have made remarks where it is quite apparent that they have not fully grasped—this is the very point Senator Campbell made—that competency based wages are fully available and fully established.

The original bill allowed junior rates to go without review forever. The Democrats have won an amendment to prevent that occurring. We are prepared to support the repeal of section 90AB in relation to junior rates only because of the new section 120B and 143(1D). We believe the exemption we supported in 1993 of excluding junior rates from age discrimination prohibition until June 1997 simply has not delivered the outcome which we sought. We wanted to see the parties, the unions and employers develop a non-discriminatory wages system for young people, and they failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Why? At the end of last year all that a joint union, employer and Labor government working party came up with was to replace the current age based junior rates in awards like the retail industry with virtually exactly the same wage rates but with the references to age replaced by references to schooling and years since school. Very smart! Very, very slippery! So a 17-year-old in the retail industry no longer gets paid 30 per cent less than an adult because they are 17 years old but because they are the first year out of year 11.

SPEECH.PARA: That ingenious Claytons ALP solution would have had the young people of Australia dancing in the street. Do you think they are mugs? That was all that was going to be delivered as a result of section 90AB. The Democrats will not be party to a sham solution. We would prefer the transition to a non-discriminatory wages system for young people to take a little longer rather than not to happen at all. Section 90AB was destined for a sham solution under Labor. We have decided to terminate the process that was leading to that solution and institute instead a pro-active test case to progress the issue.

While federal industrial relations law has been amended to act on wage discrimination against young people, no state industrial relations law has followed. Since 1993 the Arnold Labor government in South Australia, the Goss Labor government in Queensland, the Carr Labor government in New South Wales and the Labor Green majority in the Tasmanian parliament could have but have not abolished junior rates. Where is this sham passion of yours? Where is this great principle? For 13 years the Labor Party have done nothing and are still doing nothing even in the states where they have the power. The problem with them is that they do not have the soul and the philosophy they used to have. That is why they are starting to lose out in the political war. They have lost their soul.

We could be left with a bizarre situation in 1997 where federal awards might have junior rates removed but state awards, under which the majority of young people are employed, would not. Further, employers in states deemed by the new federal act to have satisfactory vetting of employment agreements in Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia could avoid the federal ban on junior rates by entering into a state employment agreement. In short, in the vitally important industries where young people are employed—retailing and hospitality—only a small minority would be likely to benefit from the provisions standing alone in the federal act. You are damned by your record in the states and federally.

BREAK.PARA: Most young workers are not paid on age related wages in the federal system. Some industries—that is, those involving physical or labouring work—pay young people standard award wages or full competency based wages. The 100,000‐odd young people who this year will commence apprenticeships or traineeships will be paid according to progress through their training, not on the basis of their age. Young people who finish training or apprenticeships move to qualified rather than age based rates of pay. In fact, junior rates apply to only about 220,000 of the 590,000 workers aged under 20.

About 70 per cent of junior rates workers are employed in the retail industry. Full‐time employment amongst this category has not grown significantly in two decades. Virtually all new youth jobs are casual or part time, including about 80 per cent of retail jobs. This makes young workers even more vulnerable to the whims of employers. Only about one in six are unionised; a key reason why there has been no significant review of junior rates, even during the review of award salary systems under the award restructuring process. They just did not matter enough to you.

A test case will require employers and the government to put up or shut up on the argument that abolishing junior rates will cost jobs. It will allow interested parties outside the union who represent only one in six young people and employers to make proposals. It will allow the AIRC to fundamentally review the unwritten assumption in current awards that young people should always be paid less than adult employees. It will give the AIRC a clear instruction from parliament to give the industrial problems of young workers the priority they have been denied due to lack of interest from both unions and employers.

Most importantly, the test case will develop principles for the replacement or modification of junior rates capable of adoption by each of the state industrial commissions. Then we will not have to rely on any Labor government who will not do it. Through the mechanism of a test case, we can achieve the review of junior rates in both federal and state awards. By way of precedent, in 1993 the Democrats moved an amendment to the Industrial Relations Act requiring the AIRC to commence a test case to examine the issue of leave to care for sick members of a worker's household.

That test case reported two years later. It was adopted by all state commissions and is now being implemented into awards. It was a highly successful process which offered a real and comprehensive solution to the then vexed questions of carers leave. We believe it can and will do the same on junior rates. It would have been easy for us to adopt the principled but wasteful and hopeless idea that we can just carry on as we were before. But we have taken a hard decision to go the right route to get this age discrimination overturned through a mechanism that we believe will work in both federal and state arenas, because we cannot rely on Labor and we have never been able to.

TALK.START.PARA: —What concerns me a bit about the solution put forward by Senator Murray—he puts the argument very lucidly, as he always does—is that he relies to a large extent on proposed section 120B, which is the requirement for the commission to report on junior rates of pay. SPEECH.PARA: It seems extraordinary to me that a body that is meant to be an arbitrator or a conciliator—to stand above the fray, as it were—is now invited to express an opinion about matters which are absolutely germane to the sorts of things that might be brought forward in an industrial dispute. That is the first question. I would like an answer to that. It is a bit like asking the Federal Court or the High Court to give its opinion about a particular constitutional issue, and then have people go before that court to debate that issue.

Perhaps I can explain myself further. If the full bench comes down in favour of youth wages, what is an employer going to think about it when he or she goes to this full bench? Or if the full bench says there ought not be full wages, what are the union or the employees going to do about it? In any event, where does the full bench get its jurisdiction on this point? I take it that this would be in the settlement of a dispute. But it is not the settlement of a dispute. It seems to me that, were you to ask it to give an opinion—because that is what this will be: provide an opinion to a minister, copies of which to be tabled in each house of parliament and debated—how can that lead to an appreciation of the commission being an independent body?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I too have listened with interest to the contributions made by the opposition and the government in this debate. Madam Chair, as you know and as your reading of my first speech and other speeches that I have made in this place attest, this is an issue which I have a great deal of interest in, a great deal of commitment to and one I feel very passionately and strongly about. Members of the ALP have referred to me on a number of occasions in the last half hour or so and have made it into a very personal debate. I am not surprised they are playing for the person in this debate, because they do not have the ball.

SPEECH.PARA: The most disappointing feature of this debate is that, yes, like Senator Woodley, I have been waiting to hear alternatives being proffered. I too support the move to a competency based training system. I too support a shift in emphasis from people's age and rates to their experience, their training levels and their skills. I do not support the notion of youth wages; I do not support the notion of exploitation of young people simply because they are young; and I do not support the idea of proffering the notion of what Senator Lundy referred to as a living wage. Senator Murray has just countered that argument.

I know that government and opposition advisers as well as members are aware that, in effect, the national training wage—the scheme that has been put forward—is a de facto aged based system. It is one thing to come in here and do political and petty point scoring. No wonder young people are cynical about politics and politicians. The youth poll surveys that we conduct every year—I might add that no other political party surveys young Australians every year—show that 98 per cent of young people do not trust us as far as they could spit a rat. The point is that they do not trust sham solutions either.

I have been waiting for months and weeks—in fact, for the three years since I was seconded to the office of former Senator Robert Bell, who, I might add, was responsible for initiating amendments that ruled out discrimination on the basis of age—for practical and workable solutions. I oppose the notion of youth wages. I also oppose the notion of a de facto wage based scheme that will still see young people and their efforts underpaid and under‐rewarded.

Unfortunately, the notion of discrimination on the basis of age—there is breathtaking hypocrisy in here this afternoon—is something that both old parties in this place have been comfortable with for 60 or 70 years. For over 60 years, both Liberal and Labor governments, be they federal or state, have done absolutely nothing about it. In 1993—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Democrats just waited.
—We did not wait.
—You just said you did. You said you just waited, waited, waited.

—We waited for a solution. We did not wait to do anything about it, because Senator Robert Bell initiated this process in 1993. He did it with the former Labor government. I do not seem to recall anyone here remembering the process of private negotiations, discussions and consultations that took place between former Senator Robert Bell and the then industrial relations minister, the member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), as part of the negotiations that the Democrats were involved in back in 1993 on their IR bill.

BREAK.PARA: Let us not misread the political realities here. This is not my preferred position. This is not a perfect solution. I do not for one minute imagine that the coalition government would incorporate my preferred position in law. What is the alternative in a political sense? The political alternative is that we—I suspect that the people on the sidelines, the ALP opposition—would see this nation go to a double disillusion, in which I have no doubt that the coalition would ram through legislation that would not necessarily treat young people kindly. So it is within that political reality that the Democrats have indicated they will oppose the amendment put forward by the ALP or support the repeal of section 90AB, and it is within that political context that they have done so.

The Australian Democrats are in the same position that we were in in 1993. We are left with the responsibility of coming up with a workable solution. In 1993, we had to come up with a workable solution, or at least initiate a process that would see junior wage rates phased out and replaced with non‐exploitative wage levels. As Senator Murray referred to, in the last three years, we have seen very little action. We have seen a joint union‐employer‐government body. Perhaps the Australian Democrats should have been present on that working party. We might have then seen a solution that did not necessarily turn out to be a de facto age based system.

It is important that we get on record the disappointment we feel towards previous and current state and federal governments. As Senator Murray said, there are state governments, both Liberal and Labor, which have had an opportunity to do something about the issue of youth wages. We have had to acknowledge that, unfortunately, the transition from a junior wage rate system to a non‐discriminatory wage based system will take a little longer than we had hoped. We have pushed for a proactive solution through an AIRC test case. We are hoping that an IRC test case will, once and for all, progress and resolve this issue.

Junior rate provisions in awards have never been reviewed. However, section 120B requires that the IRC conduct a full test case within two years; that is, it should report back to the parliament within two years on the feasibility of replacing junior rates with non-discriminatory alternatives. This report will also include an assessment of the desirability of replacing junior rates with non-discriminatory alternatives, the consequences for youth employment and the utility of junior rates for different types of employment in different industries as well as the school to work transition.

The particularly positive feature of such a test case, much along the same lines as the carer's leave test case—which was again initiated by the Australian Democrats—is that, when it comes up with a solution that is practical and fair, this will then flow on to state commissions. This will happen in the same way that the carer's leave case was adopted by all state commissions and is now being implemented. I imagine that the IRC case will pick up those state commissions.

The reality is that the majority of young workers, as we know, are employed under state awards rather than federal awards. Seventy per cent are in the retail industry and 75 per cent are in casual or part-time work. The federal abolition of junior rates would not necessarily have flowed through to state awards and agreements. No other state government, Liberal or Labor, has moved to abolish junior rates, despite the opportunity to do so and despite the fact that a majority of young people are employed under state agreements.

I am concerned about the IRC time line. I have expressed my disappointment with that. I think three years is too long. I acknowledge that, for a test case to be done properly—such as the carers leave test case—it does take time. But I would hope that this parliament and individuals—certainly Senator Kernot has pledged that she will be writing to the IRC—urge that this determination be brought down as quickly as possible so that, finally, a workable and appropriate solution is implemented.

I mentioned the political realities. This is the only reason that the Australian Democrats would agree to defer an amendment which was of their initiation. This proposal—Senator Murray used the word `sham'—actually offers a workable solution as opposed to a sham solution. It is about bringing about real change for young Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even his `sham' was not an accurate representation.

—`Sham' is an accurate representation. The proposal that we are talking about is a sham solution. By allowing the cut‐off date to exist as it currently does, there is no workable solution at the moment to ensure that young people are no longer exploited or that their wage levels are non‐discriminatory. You are merely taking away the reference to age but not providing young people with something that Senator Lundy referred to repeatedly, and that is the notion of a living wage.

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats have secured benefits for young people in this bill. It was a draconian piece of industrial relations legislation. I do not shy away from that. The Democrats have made it marginally better.

PARA.BREAK: There are a number of positive things that the Democrats have secured for young Australians in the context of this bill, whether it is requiring all enterprise agreements seeking to change apprenticeships and traineeships to be approved by the IRC or the Employment Advocate to ensure that the employees genu inely agree and that the employees will not be disadvantaged in comparison with their award; giving the IRC and the Employment Advocate an express duty to have particular regard to the interests of young workers in all their functions; expanding government reporting requirements on the impact on enterprise bargaining on vulnerable groups to include young people as well; or expanding the rights of unions to enter workplaces to investigate award breaches, such as under‐payment, without the need for a written invitation from a young worker capable of being seen by the employer. There are a number of references and I am sure that Senator Murray will continue to refer to them throughout the bill.

BREAK.PARA: We have made and negotiated these gains within the context of a regressive piece of legislation. It is against this political backdrop—this political reality—that my party has agreed to the repeal of section 90AB. I understand this rationale and understand that it was the best and only option available to the Australian Democrats. Senator Murray, all my colleagues and I remain opposed to the notion of discrimination on the basis of age. For that reason, we find this decision a difficult one.

But I think I found it more difficult this afternoon to listen to members of the opposition championing their commitment in this place to young Australians; to have one honourable senator say that this is the first and only opportunity to show a tangible commitment to young Australians. You could reel off a list of incredibly regressive and negative things that their party did for young people—whether it was cutting eligibility of the dole, introducing higher education fees, making Austudy harder to access or reducing those payments. It is just extraordinary.

This is not the only opportunity that this chamber has had to do something tangible for young Australians. But what this opportunity is about for one particular party in this chamber today is petty political point scoring. It is about attacking individuals and attacking my party because we are trying, yet again, to come up with a workable solution in a position where the two parties have failed for the past 60 years, but more previously, in the last three years.

All my colleagues are opposed to discrimination on the basis of age. All my colleagues oppose the exploitation of young people, and that means that we oppose young people being paid 40 per cent less than adult workers simply because they are young. This remains our view whether you dress it up as a national training wage; whether you dress it up as CBT; or whether you do what Hewson did in advocating a regressive $3 an hour youth wage—and the ALP quite rightly attacked him for this—while at the same time advocating a training wage and training benefits that were 40 per cent of adult rates for the same work done as adult workers.

The Democrats remain opposed to discrimination on the basis of age. This is not the first opportunity that we have had to come up with a workable solution. It is not the best. I am not happy with the time line proposed by the IRC. But this is not about scoring political points. It is about a principle. It is a principle to which we are all incredibly strongly committed. It is a principle that requires a workable, appropriate and fair solution.

I rise to make a few remarks about the annual report 1996 of Australian Defence Industries. The end of the 1995‐96 financial year marks the completion of Australian Defence Industries' six‐year restructuring program. This program was created to place the company, fully owned and operated by the Commonwealth government, on a commercial footing.

When the program started, ADI were losing around $300 million per annum. This year, they have reported an operating profit before abnormals and tax of $4.7 million. Whilst this is better than prior to 1989, it is still far less than in previous years. There was also a $34.5 million write‐off in abnormals this year. However, this is in line with ADI's budget and the 1995‐96 financial year was always intended to be one of significantly lower profits, due to the end of the corporatisation process. This is due in large part to the substantial restructuring of the munitions business, which culminated in the opening of the world-class new munitions plant at Benalla, Victoria, in August of this year.

One query did strike me as I flicked through the report. I refer particularly to page 37 where, consistent with the corporations code, the remuneration paid to directors has been outlined. It is noted, for interest, that the remuneration to, presumably, the chief executive officer of the corporation is in the range of $460,000 to $469,000. I trust that the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) is aware of this; that there are good reasons for such high payments; and that he is aware that, particularly in a year when all indicators of the company have shown it to be performing poorly, the salary and other allowances paid to the CEO are so high. I just note that in passing.
ADI is working on a number of important projects, the biggest of which is its building of six minehunter ships for the Royal Australian Navy. This project is worth around $1 billion in revenue.

One of Australia's best assets is our human resources talent in research and development. ADI's employees are no exception, and this is reflected in their construction of the Huon class minehunter, the most advanced ship of its type under construction anywhere. It boasts a variable depth sonar system, remotely controlled mine disposal vehicles and an advanced tactical data system. The ship also has multifunctional control consoles which can deliver all navigational and mine warfare data concurrently to the command team operators. This is advanced technology indeed and a reflection of the worth of those who have been contributing to this very worthwhile development.

ADI are also building a substantial export market. Recent defence export successes include: sales of ADI's live-fire training system to the USA, Thailand and the United Arab Emirates;a contract for installation of C3I—or command, control, communications and intelligence—software at the five‐power air defence headquarters in Malaysia; the sale of ADI's eye safe laser rangefinder to Canada, with units trialled in Malaysia and France; and the use of the AMASS minesweeping and support system by overseas navies, with a recent sale to the US navy for testing. Indeed, if that program should be successful in the US and implemented throughout the US navy, significant additional revenues can be anticipated.

As I speak, ADI is completing the building and manufacturing of two of its most important contracts in terms of the contribution to Australia's continued security. These are the world famous Steyr rifle and the Collins class submarine, one of the world's most advanced submarines.

ADI has also successfully moved into using its defence knowledge and capabilities for civilian applications, sold both here and overseas. These include: major sales of cellular telephone and trunked radio systems in China, India, Russia and Papua New Guinea; environmental clean-up operations in Germany, Australia and the Czech Republic; the successful completion of Papua New Guinea's primary cellular telephone network; the recovery and recycling of coal tar sludge at the Australian Gas Light Company's Mortlake site in Sydney; the emergency docking of MV Aurora Australis and work on MV Iron Monarch; the repair of soil contamination; and a contract to supply eight 140-tonne cylindrical reactor vessels for the BHP Port Hedland hot briquetted iron project in my home state of Western Australia.

One of the unfortunate sides to ADI's restructuring has been their staff reductions, with over 500 more employees leaving. Indeed, their staff complement has reduced from something over 9,000 in 1985‐86 to a little over 3,000 in this financial year. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to speak on abuse of parliamentary privilege and the recent tragic death of retired New South Wales Supreme Court judge, the Hon. David Yeldham QC. David Yeldham served the people of New South Wales in a long and distinguished legal career as one of the leaders of the Sydney bar from 1955 until 1974, and as a judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales from 1974 until his retirement in 1990. Since his retirement, he has deployed his considerable skills as a mediator and as an arbitrator in private practice.

SPEECH.PARA: I knew and admired David Yeldham—the man and the lawyer—for over 15 years. I had the privilege of appearing before him as counsel during his tenure as a Supreme Court judge. He was quick and decisive, commercially astute, and impatient of humbug. Litigants appearing before him were treated fairly and without fear or favour. He embodied the maxim that justice delayed is justice denied, and developed a formidable reputation for hard work, and quick turnaround and dispatch of reserve judgments.

David was also a widely liked and respected figure among his brother judges, the other members of the judiciary in New South Wales. I was gratified to see reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today expressions of affection for David Yeldham by former colleagues, including the former Chief Justice Sir Laurence Street, the present Chief Justice Murray Gleeson, the present New South Wales Governor the Hon. Gordon Samuels, Justice Ian Sheppard of the Federal Court, and Justice John Clarke of the New South Wales Court of Appeal.

To those expressions I can add those of my husband, the Hon. Andrew Rogers QC, a former Chief Judge of the Commercial Division who is temporarily absent overseas. Eminent members of the senior bar in Sydney have added their voices in tribute, including Tom Hughes QC and Chester Porter QC. David Yeldham's former colleagues and friends will miss his humour, his enthusiasm and his professional approach to his work.

David was a family man. I well remember his face breaking into a broad smile as he detailed the latest exploits of his beloved grandchildren or the latest success of one of his children. David was devoted not only to his own family but also to other people's families. His community service included work with the Child Accident Prevention Foundation Australia and for the National Association for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect.

I say this to his wife Anne, his children and grandchildren: as you grieve, may you be comforted by the high regard in which your husband and father was held by those who were associated with him. As a community, we are the poorer for his passing.

Ironically, his tragic early death has provided a timely opportunity for debate on the proper use of parliamentary privilege. It is now useless to speculate on whether the naming of David Yeldham by Mrs Franca Arena in the New South Wales Legislative Council, under parliamentary privilege, as potentially the recipient of favoured treatment by the New South Wales Wood royal commission in its paedophile inquiries, was causally connected to his decision to end his life. The relevant inquiry, I suggest, is how to ensure that the important and fundamental right of parliamentary privilege can be used responsibly and fairly.

The Senate provides an opportunity for a person who has been adversely referred to in the Senate to have a response incorporated in the parliamentary record without the need for exhaustive inquiry by the Privileges Committee or undue technicalities. This is one possible way to balance the competing interests of parliamentary immunity with the right of an individual not to be unjustifiably attacked.

Perhaps the most effective safeguard, however, is for all of us who have the right to claim parliamentary privilege for our utterances to keep at the forefront of our minds the profound and irremediable effect such statements can have on those attacked. I believe that there is a line to be drawn between compelling evidence on the one hand and mere suspicion, rumour, innuendo and smear on the other. In the end, we parliamentarians have to sharpen our judgments on where to properly draw this line. Outside parliament, the law requires it. Inside parliament, the test of conscience should be no less rigorous.
