At this time British Aerospace sold its Jetstream division to another European consortium. Impulse Air took legal action against British Aerospace and on 6 November 1995 was granted permission by the then Attorney-General Michael Lavarch to take proceedings under the Australian trade practices legislation.

The proceedings commenced and, whilst I do not wish to debate at length the complete saga of those legal proceedings as they are continuing, it is clearly on the record that despite many proposals for mediation between the two companies as well as proposals by Justice Einfeld, who is hearing the proceedings, British Aerospace has simply refused to come to the table. It has refused point blank to negotiate any mediation of these proceedings.

What we now have is a situation which unfortunately so often arises in litigation between small companies and large companies and, as I have said on other occasions, between unions and big employers. That is, the big company can simply outlast the small enterprise. It can drag the legal proceedings out and refuse to ever come to the party and mediate, as has been recommended on a number of occasions throughout the proceedings.

We therefore have a situation where this company has lost substantial income. In fact, this saga had a disastrous impact upon the business of Impulse Airlines. Arthur Andersen, the major accounting firm, has estimated that the failure of the aircraft supplied by Jetstream to live up to what was promised cost Impulse Air in the vicinity of $4.2 million in profit during the 10 months that they operated with those aircraft. That contrasted with the promise through the business plan which British Aerospace presented to Impulse that they would in fact make a $2.4 million profit if they used those aircraft.

What does all this have to do with the Senate and indeed the public? It has a lot to do with it, because here we have a very successful Australian enterprise providing a very necessary service to the people in regional New South Wales and Queensland. If the company goes under because of the procrastination and deliberate delaying tactics by British Aerospace, then many people in regional Australia will suffer besides the company.

At the same time, this same company, British Aerospace, is one of the major companies being considered by the Australian Department of Defence for the supply of equipment and in particular the lead‐in fighter project. A decision on which company will get to supply that lead‐in fighter will be made before Christmas this year. Whilst no doubt proper consideration will be given to the competing merits of the companies who are in the race to supply extensive defence equipment, it is a matter of grave concern that, at the same time, one of these companies not only has failed to honour its commitments made in the past to Impulse Airlines but also has treated a local enterprise with such contempt. The government needs to give very serious consideration as to whether or not this is the sort of practice that we want to see in Australia, where a company can literally drive a small or medium sized Australian enterprise to the wall in such circumstances and at the same time gain business from the Australian government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening in the adjournment debate to mention what will probably become familiar in this chamber as a hobby horse of mine, and that is the issue of employment and the issue of dignity of people. But, in particular, this evening I want to refer to the issue of casuals—casualisation—and part-time employment. I find that these two areas are very much misunderstood in the community at large and are very much abused by employers in general.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make particular reference to my lengthy experience as a trade union secretary in the retail industry—as the secretary of the SDA. Over a long period of time I was able to see the balance of employment tip from being full-time employment down to being predominantly casual. Whilst my association with the SDA went back as far as 1976, in the early part of that decade we saw the introduction of extended trading hours. I believe that, as a direct consequence of those extended trading hours, we saw the introduction in fairly large proportions of casual employees—predominantly junior casual employees—who replaced more senior people who were employed in the industry at that time.

When I joined the SDA in about 1976, the mix was about 60 per cent full time and 40 per cent casual; by the time I left, the mix had changed to about 20 per cent full time and 80 per cent casual, with the vast majority of those casuals being people who were under the age of 21. Of course, they were people with little experience of the world, little experience and little ability to bargain for their rights, and little experience and little ability to contend with the rigours of dealing with an employer.

The interesting thing is that, over this period of time, we saw entrenched in the minds of management the concept of the use of casuals, their disposability and their inability to branch out and adopt any other form of employment. Ultimately, about 25 per cent of young people employed in the retail industry are under the age of 18. This is true in many other industries now, such as the fast food industry. If you look at other service industries, again you will find a predominance of young people being employed in those jobs. My concern is their ability to bargain and their ability to secure reasonable employment.

One thing that we were able to achieve through the enterprise bargaining process was an undertaking from the employers for predominantly more secure permanent employment through part-time employment with daily minimums and maximums, weekly minimums and maximums and regular rosters, so that people could have some predictability in both their lifestyle and income and a reasonable expectation of income. This was very important because, to my knowledge, it led to a real distinction between part-time and casual employees for the first time in about 15 years. To make part-timers more attractive, they were given the right to flex up their hours. The employers accepted that this additional flexibility made them far more desirable than casual employees.

The unfortunate thing in this situation was that, whilst we went to great lengths to explain this to the employees and whilst senior management was able to grasp the concept, middle and lower level management were not able to come to grips with the concept. This is part of the problem within Australian industry. Senior people in management are able to grasp the concept, but they cannot necessarily translate it into the lower levels of management. Hence our very good concern to promote more permanency in employment through part-time employment and to offer additional flexibility was not necessarily taken up at the rate that it should have been. Instead, people were left hanging with casual employment.

Whilst casual employment may suit some people, casual employment is a very demeaning form of work if one is trying to get sufficient income by which to sustain oneself. If one is given the certainty of employment through a part-time contract without the need to be constantly at the beck and call of the employer, and with a guaranteed roster and guaranteed hours, there is the chance that one can step along the road to achieving dignity. This is a very important factor in giving young people an opportunity to see that they are something worth while.

Casualisation was definitely not the responsibility or making of the trade union movement. It evolved over time, because the employers saw the use of casual labour as a very efficient and effective means of running their business. Whilst that was their short-term view, in the longer term I believe that many employers are now forming the opinion that part-time employment, where it offers stability, is something that people will take up. Just as underemployment, be it part time or casual, is a curse, it is necessary to have people see that, with the availability of permanent employment, there is an opportunity for them to obtain some form of dignity. This is a fundamental issue. However, neither part-time nor casual employment, unfortunately, will give people the opportunity to have a career or, in the end, a very stable lifestyle. When they go into a bank, credit union or finance corporation and seek to get some form of finance facility, they find that they are turned to one side because they are in part-time or casual employment. That is a sad thing.

Whilst part-time employment is a step away from casual employment, it is desirable to make things better for younger and older people. The ultimate goal is full-time employ ment.It is only then that people will ultimately be able to achieve their dignity. The trend towards casualisation has shown no signs of stemming in some industries. This must be a grave concern for all in the community, because this will mean that created in our society will be an underclass with few rights or little ability to survive.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a March 1994 report by the Western Australian Department of Transport on the erosion of Palm Beach, Rockingham, which attributes the loss of this foreshore to the Navy causeway to HMAS Stirling .

(2) Does the department agree that the causeway has prevented the sand nourishment of the Palm Beach coastline and has consequently caused the erosion of this shoreline; if so, will the department be providing financial assistance or any other assistance to the City of Rockingham to artificially resupply the affected shoreline with sand; if not, why not.
(3) Will the department be taking any other remedial action to prevent the ongoing loss of public amenity in the interests of the ratepayers of Rockingham.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the March 1994 report by the Western Australian Department of Transport entitled `Cape Peron—Rockingham, Management of Siltation at The Entrance to the Boat Ramp Basin'.

(2) The beaches at Rockingham have always been very narrow with no dune and sand reserves. Consequently, considerable protection works have already been undertaken in the Palm Beach Hymas Road area since at least 1966.

The design of the road link from the mainland at Point Peron to Garden Island was a compromise between two conflicting requirements. During the late 1960s planning process for the causeway, which was completed in 1973, the Fremantle Port Authority favoured a full breakwater which would provide protection to a future outer harbour to be built on the southern flats of Cockburn Sound. For environmental reasons the Commonwealth favoured a bridge. The compromise design was of a rubble mound breakwater with two bridged openings to assist the movement of water into the sound. The opening closer to the mainland enables water flow to the southern shoreline of the sound.

Prior to the causeway construction the environmental impact of the structure on Cockburn Sound was assessed. A recently completed report commissioned by the Department of Defence titled `Review of the Impact of the Garden Island Causeway on the Cockburn Sound WA Environment' states that:

PARA.TAB: `The Cockburn Sound beaches, particularly those in the Rockingham area, were subjected to detailed analysis in order to determine any effects of the Causeway construction. All methods of analysis, including a statistical study of beach widths, comparison of aerial photographs (1954—1972), sediment tracking, sediment analysis and a calculation of the net yearly sediment movement, showed that the recreational beaches between Rockingham and the Causeway were dynamically stable. Dynamically stable means that in the short term (one to five years) they may show extensive accretion or erosion but in the long term the beaches will have basically a constant alignment, sand volume and cross section. The contribution of ocean swell wave energy to these beaches was always small and was eliminated by the Causeway.'

ANSWER.PARA: The causeway has reduced the wave energy approaching the beach from the west and may have also reduced the amount of sand moving along the beach. It is suspected that this has a positive result in maintaining the beach width. Thus, there is no conclusive evidence that the causeway has affected the nourishment of Palm Beach.

Recent severe storms in Western Australia—the worst for 20 years—have affected the whole coastline between Albany and Geraldton, and in all probability caused the beach erosion at Palm Beach east of the causeway to Garden Island.

Accordingly, my Department advises that it does not agree that the causeway has been responsible for the erosion of the Palm Beach coastline and therefore will not be providing any assistance to the City of Rockingham.
(3) In response to the third part of Senator Margetts' question, the Department of Defence will not be taking remedial action.
